1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish and highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	Our products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	Over our 29-year history, Vera Bradley has become a true lifestyle brand that appeals to a broad range of consumers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our brand vision is accessible luxury that inspires a casual, fun, and family-oriented lifestyle.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S4	We have positioned our brand to highlight the high quality, distinctive and vibrant styling, and functional design of our products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P0_S5	Frequent releases of new designs help keep the brand fresh and our customers continually engaged.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	We generate net revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Indirect and Direct.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	As of January 29, 2011, our Indirect business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,300 independent retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as select national retailers and third party e-commerce sites.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	As of January 29, 2011, our Direct business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products through our 35 full-price stores, our four outlet stores, verabradley.com, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	For financial information about our reportable segments, refer to Note 14 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Part II, Item 8.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P1_S4	Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this report.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	Effective January 1, 2008, we changed our fiscal year to end on the Saturday closest to January 31.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	Fiscal years ended on January 29, 2011 ( fiscal 2011 ), January 30, 2010 ( fiscal 2010 ), and January 31, 2009 ( fiscal 2009 ), and the current fiscal year will end on January 28, 2012 ( fiscal 2012 ).
1495320_11_ITEM1_P2_S2	Due to the change to a January year end, we have presented certain financial information as of and for the month ended January 31, 2008, and as of and for the year ended December 31, 2007.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Reorganization Transaction and Stock Split Vera Bradley, Inc. was formed as an Indiana corporation on June 23, 2010, for the purpose of reorganizing the corporate structure of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc., which was incorporated in Indiana on November 15, 1982.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S1	On October 3, 2010, the shareholders of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. contributed all of their shares of Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. to Vera Bradley, Inc. in return for shares of Vera Bradley, Inc.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S2	Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock on a one-for-one basis.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S3	In addition, effective October 3, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. converted from an S Corporation to a C Corporation for income-tax purposes.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S4	Further, on October 18, 2010, Vera Bradley, Inc. recapitalized all of its Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock into a single class of common stock and effectuated a 35.437-for-1 stock split of all outstanding shares of its common stock.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S5	These events collectively are referred to as the Reorganization.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S6	As a result of the Reorganization, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. became a wholly owned subsidiary of Vera Bradley, Inc.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S7	The only significant asset of Vera Bradley, Inc. is its investment in Vera Bradley Designs, Inc., and all of our operations are conducted through Vera Bradley Designs, Inc.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S8	Except where context requires or where otherwise indicated, the terms Company, Vera Bradley, we, our, and us refer to Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. and its subsidiaries before the Reorganization and to Vera Bradley, Inc. and its subsidiaries, including Vera Bradley Designs, Inc., after the Reorganization.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P3_S9	All historical common stock and per share common stock information has been changed to reflect the stock split.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our History Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller founded the Company in 1982 in Fort Wayne, Indiana, after recognizing a lack of stylish travel accessories in the market.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	named after Barbara s mother, and began manufacturing and marketing their distinctive products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	The founders, together with the executive management team, have been instrumental in our growth and success.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	The following timeline sets forth a summary of significant milestones in Vera Bradley s history:
1495320_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller launched Vera Bradley by introducing three products: the handbag, the sports bag, and the duffel bag.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	We relocated to our current headquarters in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	Ernst Young honored our Co-Founders with an Entrepreneur of the Year award.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	To accommodate the increasing number of attendees, we relocated our annual outlet sale from a tent in our parking lot to its present location at the Allen County War Memorial Coliseum in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	We founded our primary philanthropy, the Vera Bradley Foundation for Breast Cancer.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our products were being sold in all 50 states through Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	We launched the Vera Bradley Visual Merchandising Program, providing retailers a framework for presenting the brand and merchandising our products in a consistent manner.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	In addition, we launched a series of strategic initiatives to build a foundation for future growth.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	We launched our e-commerce business through our website, verabradley.com.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	We opened a state-of-the-art warehouse and distribution facility in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	In mid-September, we also opened our first store at the Natick Collection, in greater Boston, and opened six additional stores later in the year.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	We transitioned from using an independent sales force to a sales force comprised entirely of in-house, full-time employees.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	We opened five additional stores, and in early November, we opened our first outlet store at Chicago Premium Outlets in Aurora, Illinois.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	We opened a design office in New York City as well as nine additional full-price stores and three additional outlet stores, and we completed our initial public offering.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The passion for design and customer service established by our founders has driven our growth over the past 29 years and remains the cornerstone of Vera Bradley today.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	As Chief Creative Officer, Ms. Bradley Baekgaard continues to play a role in the team responsible for our day-to-day creative functions, including product development and store design.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	As our National Spokesperson, Ms. Miller continues to play a role representing the brand at events, business and community functions, and philanthropic activities.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	Evolution of Our Business Beginning in 2005, we embarked on a series of strategic initiatives designed to take advantage of the growing interest in the Vera Bradley brand.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	These initiatives were designed to strengthen and enhance our business and operating model, expand our demographic and geographic market opportunity, and position us for future growth.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	The core components of these initiatives included the following: Merchandising Strategy .
1495320_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	To appeal to a broader range of consumers, we developed a mix of pattern and product offerings specifically targeted at different consumer demographics, refined our product release strategy to significantly expand our product portfolio, and increased the number of new patterns released as well as the frequency of new product launches.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P17_S4	In addition, we substantially enhanced our visual merchandising strategy, focusing on a consistent presentation of Vera Bradley as a lifestyle brand.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	In 2006, we initiated a Direct channel strategy that was designed to expand our brand presence and broaden our consumer demographic while complementing the growing Indirect channel of our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	The first step in establishing the Direct channel of our business was selling directly to consumers through verabradley.com beginning in 2006.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	In mid-September 2007, we opened our first full-price store.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S3	In fiscal 2011, we had more than 32 million visits to verabradley.com, and as of January 29, 2011, we operated 35 full-price stores and four outlet stores.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S4	Beginning in 2005, we made a series of investments to strengthen our supply chain capabilities, information systems, and product development processes, resulting in substantial cost savings and a more flexible and scalable operating structure.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S5	During this period, we shifted our production from a primarily domestic manufacturing model to a more cost-effective global sourcing platform.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P18_S6	In 2007, we opened a state-of-the-art warehouse and distribution facility in Fort Wayne, Indiana.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Drive Comparable-Store Sales and Our E-Commerce Business.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	We have several ongoing initiatives to drive comparable-store sales growth, including focusing on store-level merchandising programs and enhancing in-store customer service and selling capabilities.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S2	As a key element of our Direct channel strategy, we will continue to grow our e-commerce business through focused marketing efforts, online merchandising initiatives, and social networking sites such as Facebook and Twitter.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S3	We believe our retail and e-commerce businesses are complementary and facilitate frequent contact with our customers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S4	We design products to accessorize a woman s life and believe this core competence serves as a platform for growth within and beyond our current product lines.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S5	We have expanded our product offerings to include new line extensions, such as our Vera Vera microfiber collection, and brand extensions, such as our paper and stationery collection.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S6	We believe that opportunities exist to accessorize a woman s life through complementary product collections that fit within our positioning as a lifestyle brand.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S7	We introduce new patterns seasonally, four times per year.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S8	Within each season, we generally introduce three to five patterns.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S9	These patterns are incorporated into the designs of a wide range of products, including handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items, that are part of the core seasonal release.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S10	These products, which constitute our Signature Collection each season, can be classic styles, updates to older designs, or new product introductions.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S11	After each seasonal launch, we release additional new collections, typically once per month throughout the season.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S12	These collections often utilize or are inspired by that season s patterns (e.g., the paper and gift collection in a new pattern), but a few of our releases are separate from the Signature Collection (e.g., the Vera Vera collection in solid colors).
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S13	We have increased the number of patterns per Signature release as well as the frequency of subsequent releases over time and believe that the assortment, breadth, and cadence allow us to reach a broader range of consumer demographics and needs.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S14	We believe this approach keeps consumers continually engaged with our brand and repeatedly shopping at our points of distribution.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S15	In addition, we believe this approach allows us to minimize the risk associated with a single pattern not performing to our expectations.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S16	To keep our assortment current and fresh and to focus our inventory investments on our best performers, we discontinue patterns from time to time.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P26_S17	We sell our remaining inventory of discontinued products at our annual outlet sale and through our website and outlet stores.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	We believe that having an in-house sales force results in more consistent brand presentation and messaging, enhanced support for our Indirect retailers, and a more predictable, scalable, and cost-efficient business model.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P42_S4	The compensation structure for our sales consultants consists of a combination of fixed pay and sales-based incentives.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P42_S5	In addition to acquiring new and growing existing accounts, our sales consultants serve as a support center for our Indirect retailers by assisting and educating them in areas such as merchandising and visual presentation, marketing of the brand, product selection, and inventory management.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P42_S6	Our sales consultants also participate in our semi-annual product introduction and education event for our Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P42_S7	Our visual merchandising program provides our sales consultants with a framework to guide our Indirect retailers regarding optimal product placement and display that is intended to reinforce the message that our brand is distinct from those of our competitors.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P43_S2	Based on the success of our existing outlet stores, the number of attractive outlet centers in the United States, and the growing popularity of outlet shopping, we believe the United States has capacity to support additional Vera Bradley outlet stores.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	This includes actual and planned penetration in both Indirect and Direct segments, as well as existing e-commerce demand.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P44_S4	At this time, we do not believe any market has been fully penetrated, and therefore, expansion of our Direct segment should positively affect our Indirect segment.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P44_S5	We believe that expansion of our store base complements our Indirect segment by increasing brand awareness and reinforcing our brand image.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	Manufacturing and Supply Chain Model Our manufacturing and supply chain model is designed to maximize flexibility in order to meet shifting demands in the market.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	Our model utilizes offshore raw material suppliers and a blend of offshore and domestic manufacturing.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S2	We place a strong emphasis on continuous improvement of the model and have employed lean manufacturing concepts.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S3	Our broad-based, multi-country manufacturing and supply chain model is designed to achieve efficient, timely, and accurate order fulfillment while maintaining appropriate levels of inventory.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S4	Our sourcing strategy is part of the larger cross-functional product development process.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S5	The overall objective for our sourcing team is to build and sustain collaborative partnerships throughout our supply chain.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P49_S6	The sourcing team leverages its expertise in negotiation, relationship management, and change management to maintain a strong global supply chain.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	The majority of our products are cotton-based.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our other products are made from specialty fabrics (including nylon and microfiber) and paper.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	We source our materials from various suppliers in Asia, with the majority coming from China and South Korea.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S3	Our global supply chain and purchasing teams work together to select suppliers that enable us to optimize the mix of cost, lead time, quality, and reliability within our global supply network.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S4	All of our suppliers must comply with our quality standards, and we use only a limited number of pre-approved suppliers who have demonstrated a commitment to delivering the highest quality products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P50_S5	In December 2008, we opened an office in Dongguan, China, which enables us to increase our control over the manufacturing and supply chain process and monitor compliance with our quality standards.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	A significant majority of our finished goods products are manufactured externally overseas.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	These products are made by a variety of global manufacturers located primarily in China.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	We are not dependent upon any single manufacturer for our products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P51_S3	When determining the size of orders placed with our manufacturers, we take into account forward-looking demand, lead times for specific products, current inventory levels, and minimum order quantity requirements.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Overseas production has resulted in substantial cost savings and reduction of capital investment.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	With the oversight of our office in China and our independent contractors, we believe these financial benefits have been realized without sacrificing the level of quality inherent in our products or service to our customers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S2	The remainder of our products are manufactured in the United States to provide flexibility in our supply chain.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S3	This production, almost all of which is internal to Vera Bradley, enables us to manufacture a finished product in as quickly as two weeks.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S4	This capability allows us to manufacture finished product to respond quickly to shifts in marketplace demand and changes in consumer preferences.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S5	In fiscal 2011, approximately 10% of our units were produced in our domestic manufacturing facility.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S6	In 2007, we consolidated our warehousing and shipping functions into one, 217,320 square-foot distribution center, located in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S7	This highly automated, computerized facility allows Vera Bradley employees to receive information directly from the order-collection center and quickly identify the products and quantity necessary for a particular order.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S8	In addition, we employ a warehouse-control system that controls the flow of our products through 5,000 feet of automated conveyer.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S9	The facility s advanced technology enables us to more accurately process and pack orders, as well as track shipments and inventory.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P52_S10	We believe that our systems for the processing and shipment of orders from our distribution center have enabled us to improve our overall customer service through enhanced order accuracy and reduced turnaround time.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	We strive to maintain the appropriate balance of inventory to enable us to provide a high level of service to our customers, including prompt and accurate delivery of our products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	We have an active sales and operations planning process that helps us balance the supply and demand issues that we encounter in our business, optimize our inventory levels, and anticipate inventory needs.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S2	Our products are shipped primarily via FedEx and common carriers to our stores, our Indirect retailers, and directly to our customers who purchase through our website.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S3	We believe we are positioned well to support the order fulfillment requirements of our growing business, including business generated through our website.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S4	We believe that high levels of automation and technology are essential to maintain our competitive position.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S5	We maintain computer hardware, systems applications, and networks to enhance and accelerate the design process, to support the sale and distribution of our products to our customers, and to improve the integration and efficiency of our operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S6	Our management information systems are designed to provide, among other things, comprehensive order processing, production, accounting, and management information for the product development, retail, sales, marketing, manufacturing, distribution, finance, and human resources functions of our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P53_S7	We use several specialized systems, including micros Retail, SAP, and ILS, for our information technology requirements.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Competition We face strong competition in each of the product lines and markets in which we compete.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	We believe that all of our products are in similar competitive positions with respect to the number of competitors they face and the level of competition within each product line.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S2	Due to the number of different products we offer, it is not practicable for us to quantify the number of competitors we face.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S3	Our products compete with other branded products within their product categories and with private label products sold by retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S4	In our Indirect business, we compete with numerous manufacturers, importers, and distributors of handbags, accessories, and other products for the limited space available for the display of such products to the consumer.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P54_S5	Moreover, the general availability of contract manufacturing allows new entrants access to the markets in which we compete, which may increase the number of competitors and adversely affect our competitive position and our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	In our Direct business, we compete against other specialty retailers, department stores, catalog retailers, gift retailers, and Internet businesses that engage in the retail sale of similar products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S1	The market for handbags, in particular, is highly competitive.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S2	Our competitors include not only established companies that are expanding their production and marketing of handbags, but also frequent new entrants to the market.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S3	We directly compete with wholesalers and direct sellers of branded handbags and accessories, such as Coach, Nine West, Liz Claiborne, and Dooney Bourke.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S4	In varying degrees, depending on the product category involved, we compete on the basis of design (aesthetic appeal), quality (construction), function, price point, distribution, and brand positioning.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S5	We believe that our primary competitive advantages are consumer recognition of our brand, customer loyalty, product development expertise, and our widespread presence through our multi-channel distribution model.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S6	Some of our competitors have achieved significant recognition for their brand names or have substantially greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other resources than we do.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P55_S7	Further, we may face new competitors and increased competition from existing competitors as we expand into new markets and increase our presence in existing markets.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	Copyrights and Trademarks The development of each new pattern includes the design of an overall print, a complementary fabric backing, and three sizes of coordinating trim materials.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P56_S1	Once developed, we generally copyright each pattern, including the print, fabric backing, and coordinating trim.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P56_S2	We currently have in excess of 300 copyrights.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	We also own all of the material trademark rights used in connection with the production, marketing, and distribution of all of our products, both in the United States and in the other countries in which our products are principally sold.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	We aggressively police our trademarks and copyrights and pursue infringers both domestically and internationally.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P57_S2	We also pursue counterfeiters domestically and internationally through leads generated internally, as well as through external sources monitoring use in the market.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P57_S3	Our trademarks will remain in existence for as long as we continue to use and renew them on their expiration dates.

1495320_11_ITEM1_P58_S2	The remaining employees were engaged in other aspects of our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P58_S3	None of our employees is represented by a union.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P58_S4	We believe that our relations with our employees are good, and we have never encountered a strike or significant work stoppage.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	Many of our imported products are subject to existing or potential duties, tariffs, or quotas that may limit the quantity of products that we may import into the United States and other countries or impact the cost of such products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	To date, we have not been restricted by quotas in the operation of our business, and customs duties have not comprised a material portion of the total cost of a majority of our products.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P59_S2	In addition, we are subject to foreign governmental regulation and trade restrictions, including U.S. retaliation against prohibited foreign practices, with respect to our product sourcing and international sales operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P59_S3	We are subject to federal, state, local, and foreign laws and regulations governing environmental matters, including the handling, transportation, and disposal of our products and our non-hazardous and hazardous substances and wastes, as well as emissions and discharges into the environment, including discharges to air, surface water, and groundwater.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P59_S4	Failure to comply with such laws and regulations could result in costs for corrective action, penalties, or the imposition of other liabilities.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	Compliance with environmental laws and regulations has not had a material effect upon our earnings or financial position.
1495320_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	If we violate any environmental obligation, however, it could have a material adverse effect on our business or financial performance.

1495320_11_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Risks Related to Our Business Changes in general economic conditions, and their impact on consumer confidence and consumer spending, could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our performance is subject to general economic conditions and their impact on levels of consumer confidence and consumer spending.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	In recent years, consumer confidence and consumer spending deteriorated significantly, influenced by fluctuating interest rates and credit availability, changing fuel and other energy costs, fluctuating commodity prices, higher levels of unemployment and consumer debt levels, reductions in net worth based on market declines, home foreclosures and reductions in home values, and general uncertainty regarding the overall future economic environment.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Consumer purchases of discretionary items, including our merchandise, generally decline during periods when disposable income is adversely affected or there is economic uncertainty, and this could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S3	In the event of another significant economic downturn, we could experience lower than expected net revenues, which could force us to delay or slow the implementation of our growth strategies and adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S4	Our inability to predict and respond in a timely manner to changes in consumer demand could adversely affect our net revenues and results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S5	Our success depends on our ability to gauge the fashion tastes of our customers and to provide merchandise that satisfies consumer demand in a timely manner.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S6	Our products must appeal to a broad range of consumers whose preferences cannot be predicted with certainty and are subject to rapid change.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S7	We cannot assure you that we will be able to continue to develop appealing patterns and styles or meet changing consumer demands in the future.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S8	If we misjudge the market for our products, we may be faced with significant excess inventories for some products and missed opportunities for other products.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S9	Merchandise misjudgments could adversely impact our net revenues and results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S10	Our results of operations could suffer if we lose key management or design associates or are unable to attract and retain the talent required for our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S11	Our performance depends largely on the efforts and abilities of our senior management and product development teams.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S12	These executives and design associates have substantial experience in our business and have made significant contributions to our growth and success.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S13	We do not have employment agreements with any of our key executives or design associates, and we do not maintain a key person life insurance policy on most of our key executives.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S14	The unexpected loss of services of certain of these individuals could have adverse impacts on our business and results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S15	As our business grows and we open new stores, we will need to attract and retain additional qualified employees and develop, train, and manage an increasing number of management-level, sales, and other employees.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S16	Competition for qualified employees is intense.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S17	We cannot assure you that we will be able to attract and retain employees as needed in the future.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S18	Our business depends on a strong brand.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S19	If we are unable to maintain and enhance our brand, then we may be unable to sell our products, which would adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P1_S20	We believe that the brand image that we have developed has contributed significantly to the success of our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Maintaining and enhancing our brand may require us to make substantial investments in areas such as product design, store operations, and community relations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	If we are unable to maintain or enhance our brand image, our results of operations would be adversely impacted.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	If we are unable to successfully implement our growth strategies or manage our growing business, our future operating results could suffer.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	The success of our growth strategies, alone or collectively, will depend on various factors, including the appeal of our product designs, retail presentation to consumers, competitive conditions, and economic conditions.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S4	If we are unsuccessful in implementing some or all of our strategies or initiatives, our future operating results could be adversely impacted.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Successful implementation of our strategies will require us to manage our growth.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S6	To manage our growth effectively, we will need to continue to increase production while maintaining strict quality control.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S7	We also will need to continue to improve and invest in our systems and processes to keep pace with planned increases in demand.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S8	We could suffer a decline in sales if our products do not continue to meet our quality control standards or if we are unable to respond adequately to increases in customer demand for our products.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S9	We may not be able to successfully open and operate new stores as planned, which could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S10	Our continued growth will depend on our ability to successfully open and operate new stores.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S11	We plan to open 14 to 16 new stores over the course of fiscal 2012 and 14 to 20 new stores during each of the following five fiscal years.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P2_S12	Our ability to successfully open and operate new stores depends on many factors, including our ability to:
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	successfully integrate new stores into our existing operations and information technology systems.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The success of new store openings may also be affected by our ability to initiate marketing efforts in advance of opening our first store in a particular region.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Additionally, we will encounter pre-operating costs and we may encounter initial losses while new stores commence operations, which could strain our resources and adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our inability to sustain levels of comparable-store sales could cause our stock price to decline.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S4	We may not be able to sustain the levels of comparable-store sales that we have experienced in the recent past.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S5	If our future comparable-store sales decline or fail to meet market expectations, then the price of our common stock could decline.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P3_S6	Also, the aggregate results of operations of our stores have fluctuated in the past and will fluctuate in the future.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Numerous factors influence comparable-store sales, including fashion trends, competition, national and regional economic conditions, pricing, inflation, the timing of the release of new merchandise and promotional events, changes in our merchandise mix, inventory shrinkage, marketing programs, and weather conditions.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	In addition, many companies with retail operations have been unable to sustain high levels of comparable-store sales during and after periods of substantial expansion.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	These factors may cause our comparable-store sales results to be lower in the future than in recent periods or lower than expectations, either of which could result in a decline in the price of our common stock.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We are subject to risks associated with leasing substantial amounts of space, including future increases in occupancy costs.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We do not own any real estate other than our warehouse and distribution facility.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	We lease our corporate headquarters, our other offices, and all of our store locations.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	We typically occupy our stores under operating leases with terms of ten years.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S4	We have been able to negotiate favorable rental rates in recent years due in part to the state of the economy and high vacancy rates within some shopping centers, but there is no assurance that we will be able to continue to negotiate such favorable terms.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S5	Some of our leases have early cancellation clauses, which permit the lease to be terminated by us or the landlord if certain sales levels are not met in specific periods or if the shopping center does not meet specified occupancy standards.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S6	In addition to requiring future minimum lease payments, some of our store leases provide for the payment of common area maintenance charges, real property insurance, and real estate taxes.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S7	Many of our lease agreements have escalating rent provisions over the initial term and any extensions.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S8	As we expand our store base, our lease expense and our cash outlays for rent under lease agreements will increase.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P5_S9	Our substantial operating lease obligations could have significant negative consequences, including:
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	limiting our ability to obtain additional financing.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Any of these consequences could place us at a disadvantage with respect to our competitors.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We depend on cash flow from operating activities to pay our lease expenses and to fulfill our other cash needs.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	If our business does not generate sufficient cash flow from operating activities to fund these expenses and needs, we may not be able to service our lease expenses, grow our business, respond to competitive challenges, or fund our other liquidity and capital needs, which would harm our business.
1495320_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Additional sites that we lease may be subject to long-term non-cancelable leases if we are unable to negotiate our current standard lease terms.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish and highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	Over our 29-year history, Vera Bradley has become a true lifestyle brand that appeals to a broad range of consumers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S3	Our brand vision is accessible luxury that inspires a casual, fun, and family-oriented lifestyle.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S4	We have positioned our brand to highlight the high quality, distinctive and vibrant styling, and functional design of our products.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S5	Frequent releases of new designs help keep the brand fresh and our customers continually engaged.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S6	We generate revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Indirect and Direct.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S7	As of January 29, 2011, our Indirect business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,300 independent retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as to select national retailers and independent e-commerce sites.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S8	As of January 29, 2011, our Direct business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products through our 35 full-price stores, four outlet stores, verabradley.com, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S9	We began selling directly to consumers through verabradley.com in 2006, and we opened our first retail store in 2007.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S10	In recent years, we have grown rapidly as a result of the successful implementation of strategic initiatives.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S11	These initiatives included enhancing our merchandising strategy, establishing a multi-channel distribution sales model, and expanding our supply chain capabilities, product development processes, and information systems to improve operational flexibility and profitability.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S12	Due to the implementation of these key strategic initiatives, we experienced substantial growth in calendar years 2006 and 2007 as the Vera Bradley brand gained broader exposure in the marketplace.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S13	The introduction in 2006 of Java Blue, the best selling pattern in our history, also significantly influenced our growth during this period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S14	We attribute the success of Java Blue to the pattern s universal appeal across all demographic segments of our customer base and its ability to attract many consumers to the Vera Bradley brand for the first time.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S15	While sales of Java Blue patterned products contributed meaningfully to our growth in 2006 and 2007, the popularity of Java Blue also positively impacted the sales of our products in other Vera Bradley patterns during the same period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S16	During this period, our net revenues grew from $189.1 million in calendar year 2006 to $281.1 million in calendar year 2007.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S17	In fiscal 2009, our net revenues declined $42.5 million, or 15.1%, as the economic environment weakened.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S18	Consumer purchases of handbags and accessories generally decline during recessionary periods and other periods where disposable income is adversely affected.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S19	For our Indirect retailers, the majority of which are independent small businesses, this resulted in reduced traffic and a decline in sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S20	In addition to being impacted by softening consumer demand from our Indirect retailers and other consumers, our net revenues were negatively impacted by excess inventory levels held by our Indirect retailers at the end of calendar year 2007.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P1_S21	Excess inventory levels resulted from the rapidly deteriorating economic environment following a period of increasing consumer demand for our products in 2006 and 2007 and the sharp increase in orders from our Indirect retailers following the introduction of our Java Blue pattern.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	effects of softening demand and excess inventory.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	In fiscal 2009, during the challenging environment presented by the economic recession, we focused our efforts on managing our cost structure and reducing inventories while continuing to invest in our infrastructure to support future growth.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	As a result, in fiscal 2009 our operating income decreased to $27.2 million.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	In fiscal 2010, we experienced strong sales growth with net revenues of $288.9 million, an increase of 21.1% over fiscal 2009, despite the continued economic recession.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	This growth was driven by the impact of our strategic initiatives, including our expanding Direct business, the reduction of inventory levels in our Indirect channel that had occurred by the end of fiscal 2009 and increasing demand based on improving consumer confidence.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S4	In addition, fiscal 2010 net revenues in both the Indirect and Direct segments benefited from the increased frequency of releases of our collections, as well as the expansion of our range of patterns.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S5	During the same period, operating income increased to $45.7 million, or 68.1%, due primarily to the increase in net revenues combined with operational and supply chain improvements that enhanced our gross margin and operating margin.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S6	In fiscal 2011, we again achieved strong sales growth, with net revenues of $366.1 million, an increase of 26.7% over fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S7	This growth was driven primarily by our expanding Direct business, growing product assortment, improving economic conditions, and increasing brand awareness.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S8	During fiscal 2011, we remained focused on executing our growth strategies, which included growing in underpenetrated markets and expanding our U.S. store base and product offerings.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S9	In doing so, we opened nine full-price and three outlet stores, delivered four Signature Collection releases with more patterns than ever before, continued to widen the assortment of our paper collection, and released a greater number of other collections, including a special gift collection during the Christmas holiday season.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S10	We also achieved strong operating income growth.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S11	Fiscal 2011 operating income, which included $21.9 million of stock-based and other compensation expense related to restricted-stock awards that vested upon our October 2010 initial public offering, increased 16.6% to $53.3 million.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S12	We believe the combination of our expanding product offerings and continued growth in underpenetrated markets will lead to meaningful growth opportunities in fiscal 2012.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S13	We believe there is a significant opportunity to grow our store base, as we believe the market in the United States can support at least 300 Vera Bradley full-price stores.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S14	To that end, during fiscal 2011, we opened nine full-price stores and three outlet stores.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S15	We expect our full-price stores to average approximately 1,800 square feet per store, and we expect to invest approximately $0.4 million per new store, consisting of inventory costs, pre-opening costs and build-out costs less tenant-improvement allowances.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P3_S16	New full-price stores are expected to generate on average between $1.1 million and $1.3 million in net revenues during the first twelve months, and the payback on our investment is expected to occur in less than 18 months.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Typically, we have found that, as a new store becomes better integrated into its community and brand awareness grows, the store s productivity tends to improve as measured by comparable-store sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe our business strategy will continue to offer significant opportunity, but it also presents risks and challenges.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	These risks and challenges include that we may not be able to effectively predict and respond to changing fashion trends and customer preferences, that we may not be able to find desirable locations for new stores, and that we may not be able to effectively manage our future growth.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P4_S3	Addressing these risks could divert our attention from continuing to build on the strengths that we believe have driven the growth of our business, but we believe our focus on brand identity, customer loyalty, a distinctive shopping experience, product development expertise, and company culture will contribute positively to our results.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	How We Assess the Performance of Our Business In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of performance and financial measures.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Net Revenues Net revenues reflect revenues from the sale of our merchandise and from distribution and shipping and handling fees, less returns and discounts.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	Revenues for the Indirect segment reflect revenues from sales to Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	Revenues for the Direct segment reflect revenues from sales through our full-price and outlet stores, verabradley.com, and our annual outlet sale.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P6_S3	Comparable-Store Sales Comparable-store sales are calculated based upon our stores that have been open at least 12 full fiscal months as of the end of the reporting period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P6_S4	Remodeled stores are included in comparable-store sales unless the store was closed for a portion of the current or comparable prior period or the remodel resulted in a significant change in square footage.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Some of our competitors and other retailers calculate comparable or same store sales differently than we do.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	As a result, data in this report regarding our comparable-store sales may not be comparable to similar data made available by other companies.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	Non-comparable store sales include sales from stores not included in comparable-store sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	Measuring the change in year-over-year comparable-store sales allows us to evaluate how our store base is performing.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	Various factors affect our comparable-store sales, including:
1495320_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	The timing and success of promotional and advertising efforts.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	Gross Profit Gross profit is equal to our net revenues less our cost of sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Cost of sales includes the direct cost of purchased and manufactured merchandise, distribution center costs, operations overhead, duty, and all inbound freight costs incurred.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The components of our reported cost of sales may not be comparable to those of other retail and wholesale companies.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	Gross profit can be impacted by changes in volume, operational efficiencies, such as leveraging of fixed costs, promotional activities, such as free shipping, and fluctuations in pricing structures within e-commerce and the annual outlet sale.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	Price changes in the Indirect and Direct channels, excluding e-commerce and the annual outlet sale, have had an insignificant impact.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Prior to calendar year 2006, we sourced the majority of our finished products domestically.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	Today, the significant majority of our products are sourced internationally.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	During this same period, we began direct sourcing of our raw materials and brought management of logistics in-house.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P12_S3	These sourcing changes, along with better cost management, contributed to improvements in gross margin over this period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	Gross margin measures gross profit as a percentage of our net revenues.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	Selling, General, and Administrative Expenses (SG A) SG A expenses fall into three categories: (1) selling; (2) advertising, marketing, and product development; and (3) administrative.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	Selling expenses include Direct business expenses such as store expenses, employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs, as well as Indirect business expenses consisting primarily of employee compensation and other expenses associated with sales to Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	Advertising, marketing, and product development expenses include employee compensation, media costs, creative production expenses, marketing agency fees, new product design costs, public relations expenses, and market research expenses.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S3	A portion of our advertising expenses may be reimbursed by Indirect retailers, and such amount is classified as other income.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S4	Administrative expenses include compensation costs for corporate functions, corporate headquarters occupancy costs, consulting and software expenses, and charitable donations.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S5	SG A expenses increase as the number of stores increases, but not in the same proportion as the associated increase in revenues.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S6	Other Income We support many of our Indirect retailers marketing efforts by distributing certain catalogs and promotional mailers to current and prospective customers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S7	Our Indirect retailers reimburse us for a portion of the cost to produce these materials.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S8	Reimbursement received is recorded as other income.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S9	The related cost to design, produce, and distribute the catalogs and mailers is recorded as SG A expense.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S10	Operating Income Operating income equals gross profit less SG A expenses plus other income.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P14_S11	Operating income excludes interest income, interest expense, and income taxes.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Income Taxes Prior to October 3, 2010, we were taxed as an S Corporation for federal income tax purposes under Section 1362 of the Internal Revenue Code, and therefore were not subject to federal and state income taxes (subject to exception in a limited number of state and local jurisdictions that do not recognize the S Corporation status).
1495320_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	On October 3, 2010, our S Corporation status automatically terminated and we became subject to corporate-level federal and state income taxes at prevailing corporate rates.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	As a result of this change, fiscal 2009 included activity for more than 52 weeks.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P16_S3	This was a one-time occurrence and did not have a material effect on our results of operations.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	Fiscal 2011 Compared to Fiscal 2010 Net Revenues For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $77.2 million, or 26.7%, to $366.1 million, from $288.9 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S2	For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $22.1 million, or 11.5%, to $214.9 million, from $192.8 million for fiscal 2010, due primarily to increased sales volume to our Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S3	The increased sales volume resulted primarily from greater demand for our Signature Collection releases that, in most cases, had more patterns and styles relative to fiscal 2010 releases, increased offerings and sales of non-Signature Collection products, and improved economic conditions.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S4	For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $55.0 million, or 57.2%, to $151.1 million, from $96.1 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S5	This growth resulted from a $22.8 million increase in e-commerce revenues due primarily to greater traffic resulting from marketing initiatives, a $22.6 million increase in non-comparable store sales, and a $7.3 million, or 25.8%, increase in comparable-store sales due primarily to increased store traffic.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S6	The number of our stores grew from 27 at the end of fiscal 2010 to 39 at the end of fiscal 2011.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S7	In addition, our annual outlet sale revenues increased by $2.3 million due to an increase in the number of shoppers that attended the sale and higher average product pricing at the sale.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S8	Gross Profit For fiscal 2011, gross profit increased $58.0 million, or 38.4%, to $209.1 million, from $151.1 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S9	As a percentage of net revenues, gross profit increased to 57.1% for fiscal 2011, from 52.3% for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P21_S10	The increase in gross margin was due primarily to increased leverage of fixed costs as a result of the volume growth, improved efficiency in our utilization of raw materials as a result of our expanding outlet store channel, higher average product pricing at the annual outlet sale, and an overall revenue mix shift toward higher margin, retail-store sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	For fiscal 2011, SG A expenses increased $46.9 million, or 40.4%, to $163.1 million, from $116.2 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 44.5% and 40.2% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	For fiscal 2011, selling expenses increased $19.9 million, or 36.0%, to $75.3 million, from $55.4 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	The increase in selling expenses was due primarily to increased store operational costs attributable to new store openings as well as e-commerce and store marketing initiatives to drive increased traffic.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	The increase in selling expenses also resulted from the company holding two product introduction and educational events (or Premieres) for Indirect retailers during fiscal 2011, compared to only one event during fiscal 2010, and from other increased expenses as a result of the increase in net revenues.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S2	These increases were partially offset by a $1.3 million asset-impairment charge, as further described below, recorded in fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S3	No such charge was recorded in fiscal 2011.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S4	For fiscal 2011, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses decreased $1.1 million, or 3.7%, to $28.7 million, from $29.8 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S5	As a percentage of net revenues, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses were 7.8% and 10.3% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S6	This decrease resulted primarily from reduced expenses associated with our co-op marketing programs as a result of refining the marketing support for our Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S7	These reduced expenses were offset in part by increased spending on non-co-op advertising and marketing efforts and by higher employee and other costs associated with our expanded product design capabilities and with the increase in net revenues.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S8	For fiscal 2011, administrative expenses increased $28.1 million, or 90.7%, to $59.0 million, from $30.9 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S9	As a percentage of net revenues, administrative expenses were 16.1% and 10.7% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S10	This increase was due primarily to $15.8 million of stock-based compensation expense associated with the vesting of restricted-stock awards in connection with our initial public offering as well as $6.1 million of expense associated with bonuses paid to recipients of the restricted-stock awards to satisfy tax obligations.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S11	In addition, we incurred higher corporate personnel and other costs necessary to support our growth as well as increased professional services fees related in part to our transition from a private to a public company.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S12	Other Income For fiscal 2011, other income decreased $3.5 million, or 32.7%, to $7.2 million, from $10.7 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P23_S13	This decrease was due to the above-discussed refinement of the marketing support for our Indirect retailers, which resulted in decreased reimbursement of our advertising expenses.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Operating Income For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $7.6 million, or 16.6%, to $53.3 million, from $45.7 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, operating income was 14.6% and 15.8% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P24_S2	This decrease in operating income as a percentage of net revenues was due primarily to the previously discussed $15.8 million of stock-based compensation expense associated with the vesting of restricted-stock awards in connection with our initial public offering and the $6.1 million of expense associated with bonuses paid to recipients of the restricted-stock awards.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P24_S3	Operating income for our business segments is provided below.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P24_S4	Certain prior-year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current-year presentation.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $19.1 million, or 26.2%, primarily as a result of the previously discussed increase in gross profit.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	This increase was partially offset by increased selling expenses, as previously discussed.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P25_S2	For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $21.1 million, or 83.7%, primarily as a result of the previously discussed increase in gross profit.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	Fiscal 2010 Compared to Fiscal 2009 Net Revenues For fiscal 2010, net revenues increased $50.4 million, or 21.1%, to $288.9 million, from $238.6 million for fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	For fiscal 2010, net revenues increased $25.4 million, or 15.2%, to $192.8 million, from $167.5 million for fiscal 2009 due primarily to increased sales volume to our Indirect retailers.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	The volume increase resulted from improving economic conditions resulting in increased consumer spending.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S3	For fiscal 2010, net revenues increased $25.0 million, or 35.1%, to $96.1 million, from $71.1 million for fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S4	The increase resulted from a $19.1 million increase in e-commerce revenues due primarily to greater traffic from marketing initiatives.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S5	In addition, the number of our stores grew from 21 at the end of fiscal 2009 to 27 at the end of fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S6	Non-comparable store sales increased by $8.4 million and comparable-store sales increased by $5.3 million, or 36.4%.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S7	These increases were offset by a decrease in annual outlet sale revenues of $7.8 million, as we held two outlet sales in fiscal 2009 rather than the traditional one outlet sale.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P26_S8	Gross Profit For fiscal 2010, gross profit increased $28.0 million, or 22.8%, to $151.1 million, from $123.1 million in the comparable prior-year period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	profit by $25.9 million, and the remaining $2.1 million was due primarily to the improvement in gross margin to 52.3% in fiscal 2010 from 51.6% in fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	The gross margin improvement of $2.1 million was attributable to better cost management in the Direct business, improved profits from e-commerce related to fulfillment integration, and fewer promotional activities.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	For fiscal 2010, SG A expenses increased $7.0 million, or 6.4%, to $116.2 million, from $109.2 million for fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S3	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 40.2% and 45.8% during fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2009, respectively.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S5	For fiscal 2010, selling expenses increased $4.0 million, or 7.8%, to $55.4 million, from $51.4 million for fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S6	As a percentage of net revenues, selling expenses were 19.2% and 21.5% during fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2009, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S7	The increase in selling expenses was due primarily to increased depreciation related to the long-lived asset impairment for three of our stores and to increased store operating costs related to the opening of six new stores in fiscal 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S8	The asset impairment charge of $1.3 million was based on a variety of factors, including anticipated low levels of traffic and low levels of brand awareness around the store locations.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S9	These factors contributed to projected cash flows being less than the carrying amounts for those stores.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S10	These three store locations were among the early openings under our Direct channel strategy.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S11	We continue to refine our site selection process and unit economics for each new store opening by adjusting the assumptions underlying cash flow projections for each store based on historical store performance.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P27_S12	In addition to analyzing store economics, we pay particular attention to the location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies in our site selection process.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	For fiscal 2010, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses decreased $4.5 million, or 13.1%, to $29.8 million, from $34.3 million for fiscal 2009.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses were 10.3% and 14.4% during fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2009, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P28_S2	The decrease was due to a decline in the number of catalogs and direct mailers we produced as a result of lower participation by our Indirect retailers in these programs primarily due to changes in the mix of catalogs and mailers offered and a decrease in other advertising expenses.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P28_S7	The decrease was due to a decline in the participation by our Indirect retailers in our catalogs and direct mailers, which resulted in decreased reimbursement of our advertising expenses.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P28_S8	The decline in participation was due primarily to changes in the mix of catalogs and mailers offered, offset by increased company advertising.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	Amended and Restated Credit Agreement On October 4, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. entered into an agreement to amend and restate its credit agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, as administrative agent, and certain other lenders.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	The amended and restated credit agreement provides for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million and matures on October 3, 2015.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	All borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement are collateralized by substantially all of the company s assets.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S3	The credit agreement is also guaranteed by the company.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S4	The credit agreement requires the company to comply with various financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.20 to 1.00 and a leverage ratio of not more than 3.50 to 1.00.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S5	The agreement also contains various other covenants, including restrictions on the incurrence of certain indebtedness, liens, investments, acquisitions, and asset sales.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P37_S6	The company was in compliance with these covenants as of January 29, 2011.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	Borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement bear interest at either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	The applicable margin is tied to the company s leverage ratio.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	In addition, the company is required to pay a quarterly facility fee (as defined in the agreement) ranging from 0.20% to 0.45% of the revolving credit commitment.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P38_S3	At January 29, 2011, the weighted-average interest rate on the $66.75 million of outstanding borrowings under the credit agreement was 1.68%.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P38_S4	The company had borrowing availability of $58.25 million under the agreement as of January 29, 2011.

1495320_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of our assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	We evaluate our accounting policies, estimates, and judgments on an on-going basis.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P45_S2	We base our estimates and judgments on historical experience and various other factors that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P45_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions and conditions.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P45_S4	We evaluate the development and selection of our critical accounting policies and estimates and believe that the following policies and estimates involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity and are most significant to reporting our results of operations and financial position, and are therefore discussed as critical.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	The following critical accounting policies reflect the significant estimates and judgments used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	With respect to critical accounting policies, even a relatively minor variance between actual and expected experience can potentially have a materially favorable or unfavorable impact on subsequent results of operations.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	Our historical results for the periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, however, have not been materially impacted by such variances.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P47_S2	More information on all of our significant accounting policies can be found in Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from the sale of our products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an estimate of shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	The estimate of these shipments is based on shipping terms and historical delivery times.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	Significant changes in shipping terms or delivery times could materially impact our revenues in a given period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	We reserve for projected merchandise returns based on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	Merchandise returns are often resalable merchandise and in the Direct business are refunded by issuing the same payment tender of the original purchase and in the Indirect business the customer is issued a credit to its account to apply to outstanding invoices.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	Merchandise exchanges of the same product at the same price are not considered merchandise returns.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P50_S2	Product returns are often resalable through our annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P50_S3	Additionally, we reserve for other potential product credits and for customer shipments not yet received.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	$1.7 million and $1.9 million at January 29, 2011, and January 30, 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	This represents a reduction to operating income of $1.2 million and $1.3 million, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P52_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P52_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P52_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	We record valuation adjustments to our inventories, which are reflected in cost of sales, if the cost of specific inventory items on hand exceeds the amount we expect to realize from the ultimate sale or disposal of the inventory.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	This adjustment calculation requires us to make assumptions and estimates, which are based on factors such as merchandise seasonality, historical trends, and estimated sales and inventory levels, including sell-through of remaining units.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S2	In addition, as part of inventory adjustments, we provide for inventory shrinkage based on historical trends from our physical inventory counts.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S3	We perform physical inventory counts throughout the year and adjust the shrink provision accordingly.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S4	Inventory adjustments of $5.1 million and $7.5 million were recorded for these matters as of January 29, 2011, and January 30, 2010, respectively.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S5	These adjustments related primarily to raw materials of discontinued patterns, as we have the ability to move discontinued finished goods through a number of channels, including the annual outlet sale, our website and outlet stores, and through liquidators as needed.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P53_S6	The decrease in the valuation adjustments during fiscal 2011 resulted primarily from our expanding outlet store channel, which we launched in November 2009 and which has enabled us to increase our use of raw materials of discontinued patterns.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	Income Taxes Prior to October 3, 2010, we were taxed as an S Corporation for income-tax purposes under Section 1362 of the Internal Revenue Code and therefore were not subject to federal and state income taxes (subject to exception in a limited number of state and local jurisdictions that did not recognize the S Corporation status).
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S1	On October 3, 2010, our S Corporation status automatically terminated and we became subject to corporate-level federal and state income taxes at prevailing corporate rates.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S2	As a result of this conversion, effective October 3, 2010, we account for income taxes and the related accounts using the liability method in accordance with ASC 740, Income Taxes.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S3	Our effective tax rate is based on our pre-tax income, statutory tax rates, tax laws and regulations, and tax planning opportunities available in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S4	Significant judgment is required in determining our annual tax expense and in evaluating our tax positions.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P54_S5	We establish reserves to remove some or all of the tax benefit of any of our tax positions at the time we determine that the positions become uncertain based upon one of the following: (1) the tax position is not more likely than not to be sustained; (2) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but for a lesser amount; or (3) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but not in the financial period in which the tax position was originally taken.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Taxing authorities periodically audit our income tax returns.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	We believe that our tax filing positions are reasonable and legally supportable.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P55_S2	Taxing authorities, however, may take a contrary position.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P55_S3	Our results of operations and effective tax rate in a given period could be impacted if, upon final resolution with taxing authorities, we prevail in positions for which we have established reserves, or are required to pay amounts in excess of established reserves.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	Valuation of Long-lived Assets Property, plant, and equipment assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	In evaluating an asset for recoverability, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset at the store level, the lowest identifiable level of cash flow, if applicable.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P57_S1	If the sum of the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the asset is less than the carrying value, we recognize a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, usually determined by an estimated discounted cash flow analysis of the asset.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	valuation of long-lived assets include, but are not limited to, our plans for future operations, brand initiatives, recent operating results, and projected future cash flows.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	With respect to our stores, we analyze store economics, location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies in our selection process.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Impairment charges are included in SG A expenses.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	The discounted cash flow models used to estimate the applicable fair values involve numerous estimates and assumptions that are highly subjective.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	Changes to these estimates and assumptions could materially impact the fair value estimates.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P61_S2	The estimates and assumptions critical to the overall fair value estimates include: (1) estimated future cash flow generated at the store level; and (2) discount rates used to derive the present value factors used in determining the fair values.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P61_S3	These and other estimates and assumptions are impacted by economic conditions and our expectations and may change in the future based on period-specific facts and circumstances.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P61_S4	If economic conditions were to deteriorate, future impairment charges may be required.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	The restricted shares of our common stock granted under the 2010 Restricted Stock Plan were measured at fair value on July 30, 2010, the grant date.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	In the absence of a public trading market, we considered numerous objective and subjective factors, including information provided by an independent valuation firm, to determine our best estimate of the fair value of the restricted shares of our common stock on the grant date.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S2	Our estimate of this stock-based compensation was equivalent to the fair value of our common stock that was ultimately expected to vest.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S3	The stock-based compensation was recognized as compensation expense over the period the restrictions were to lapse and, then, in full upon the initial public offering of our stock.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S4	At the grant date, we estimated a forfeiture rate of zero.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S5	On the grant date, we were a private company with no active public market for our common stock.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S6	Therefore, we determined the estimated per share fair value of our common stock as of July 30, 2010, using a contemporaneous valuation consistent with the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants Practice Aid, Valuation of Privately-Held Company Equity Securities Issued as Compensation (the Practice Aid ).
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S7	In conducting this valuation, we considered all objective and subjective factors that we believed to be relevant, including our best estimate of our business condition, prospects, and operating performance at July 30, 2010.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P62_S8	Within this contemporaneous valuation performed by us, a range of factors, assumptions, and methodologies were used.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	condition of and outlook for the handbag, accessories, and luggage industries.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	After considering the information presented by our management, our board of directors rendered its final fair value determination.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P63_S2	For the contemporaneous valuation of our common stock, management estimated, as of July 30, 2010, the valuation date, our enterprise value on a continuing operations basis, using primarily the income and market approaches, both of which are acceptable valuation methods in accordance with the Practice Aid.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P63_S3	The income approach utilized the discounted cash flow ( DCF ) methodology based on our financial forecasts and projections, as detailed below.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P63_S4	The market approach utilized the market multiple methodology based on comparable public companies equity pricing, as detailed below.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	For the DCF methodology, we prepared detailed annual projections of future cash flows through 2024, which we refer to as the discrete projection period.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	annual long-term growth rate and in which the terminal-year cash flow is capitalized at a rate equal to the estimated discount rate less the estimated constant annual long-term growth rate.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	Our projections of future cash flows were based on our estimated net debt-free cash flows and were discounted to the valuation date at an estimate of our weighted-average cost of capital.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	For the market multiple methodology, we determined, as of the valuation date, a range of trading multiples for a group of comparable public companies, based on trailing 12 months adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ( EBITDA ) and adjusted earnings before interest and taxes ( EBIT ) and projected future EBITDA and EBIT.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	These multiples were then applied to our actual trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA and EBIT and projected EBITDA and EBIT as of the valuation date.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	When selecting comparable companies, consideration was given to industry similarity, their specific products offered, financial data availability and capital structure.
1495320_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	We believe that the procedures employed in the DCF and market multiple methodologies are reasonable and consistent with the Practice Aid.
