1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish and highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S2	Over our 30-year history, Vera Bradley has become a true lifestyle brand that appeals to a broad range of consumers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S3	Our brand vision is accessible luxury that inspires a casual, fun, and family-oriented lifestyle.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S4	We have positioned our brand to highlight the high quality, distinctive and vibrant styling, and functional design of our products.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S5	Frequent releases of new designs help keep the brand fresh and our customers continually engaged.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S6	We generate revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S7	As of January 28, 2012, our Direct business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products through our 48 full-price stores and eight outlet stores in the United States, seven temporary, pop-up stores in Japan, our websites, verabradley.com and verabradley.co.jp, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S8	We began selling directly to consumers through verabradley.com in calendar year 2006, opened our first retail stores in calendar year 2007, and entered the Japanese market in calendar year 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P1_S9	As of January 28, 2012, our Indirect business consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,300 specialty retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as to select national retailers and independent e-commerce retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	In recent years, we have grown rapidly as a result of the successful implementation of strategic initiatives.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	These initiatives included enhancing our merchandising strategy, establishing a multi-channel distribution sales model, expanding our supply chain capabilities, product development processes, and information systems to improve operational flexibility and profitability.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	In fiscal 2012, we continued to experience strong demand for our brand across all of our sales channels, as reflected in our net revenue growth of 26.0%.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	In our Direct segment, net revenues increased 49.1%, including an increase of $39.4 million in revenues related to the opening of new stores, a $28.6 million, or 35.3%, increase in e-commerce revenues, and a comparable-store sales increase of 10.9%.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	In our Indirect segment, net revenues increased 9.6%, driven primarily by the strength of product offerings, improved productivity through our retail partners, and the sale of certain retired inventory.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	Additionally, we achieved operating income of $96.2 million for the fiscal year ended January 28, 2012, compared to an operating income of $53.3 million in the fiscal year ended January 29, 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S6	Operating income for fiscal 2011, included $21.9 million of compensation expense related to restricted-stock awards.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S7	We remain focused on executing our growth strategies, which includes growing in underpenetrated markets and expanding our store base and product offering.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S8	We believe there is a significant opportunity to grow our store base, as we believe the market in the United States can support at least 300 Vera Bradley full-price stores.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S9	To that end, in fiscal 2012 we opened 13 full-price stores and four outlet stores and began retail operations in three new states.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S10	We partnered with Dillard s to launch our products in 65 locations.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S11	We also introduced our brand in Japan through a combination of pop-up stores and the launch of a Japanese-language website.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S12	We also began an expansion of approximately 200,000 square-feet of our distribution facility in Roanoke, Indiana.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P2_S13	We believe the combination of our expanding product offerings and continued growth in underpenetrated markets will lead to meaningful growth opportunities in the coming years.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	We expect our full-price stores to average approximately 1,800 square feet per store, and we expect to invest approximately $0.4 million per new store, consisting of inventory costs, pre-opening costs and build-out costs less tenant-improvement allowances.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	New full-price stores are expected to generate on average between $1.1 million and $1.3 million in net revenues during the first twelve months, and the payback on our investment is expected to occur in less than 18 months.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	Typically, we have found that, as a new store becomes better integrated into its community and brand awareness grows, the store s productivity tends to improve as measured by comparable-store sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe our business strategy will continue to offer significant opportunity, but it also presents risks and challenges.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	These risks and challenges include that we may not be able to effectively predict and respond to changing fashion trends and customer preferences, that we may not be able to find desirable locations for new stores, and that we may not be able to effectively manage our future growth.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P4_S3	Addressing these risks could divert our attention from continuing to build on the strengths that we believe have driven the growth of our business, but we believe our focus on brand identity, customer loyalty, a distinctive shopping experience, product development expertise, and company culture will contribute positively to our results.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	How We Assess the Performance of Our Business In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of performance and financial measures.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	Net Revenues Net revenues reflect revenues from the sale of our merchandise and from distribution and shipping and handling fees, less returns and discounts.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Revenues for the Direct segment reflect sales through our full-price and outlet stores, pop-up stores in Japan, our websites, verabradley.com and verabradley.co.jp, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	Revenues for the Indirect segment reflect sales to Indirect specialty retailers and department stores.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P6_S3	Comparable-Store Sales Comparable-store sales are calculated based upon our stores that have been open at least 12 full fiscal months as of the end of the reporting period.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P6_S4	Remodeled stores are included in comparable-store sales unless the store was closed for a portion of the current or comparable prior period or the remodel resulted in a significant change in square footage.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	Some of our competitors and other retailers calculate comparable or same store sales differently than we do.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	As a result, data in this report regarding our comparable-store sales may not be comparable to similar data made available by other companies.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	Non-comparable store sales include sales from stores not included in comparable-store sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	Measuring the change in year-over-year comparable-store sales allows us to evaluate how our store base is performing.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	Various factors affect our comparable-store sales, including:
1495320_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	The timing and success of promotional and advertising efforts.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Gross Profit Gross profit is equal to our net revenues less our cost of sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Cost of sales includes the direct cost of purchased and manufactured merchandise, distribution center costs, operations overhead, duty, and all inbound freight costs incurred.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	The components of our reported cost of sales may not be comparable to those of other retail and wholesale companies.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Gross profit can be impacted by changes in volume, operational efficiencies, such as leveraging of fixed costs, promotional activities, such as free shipping, commodity prices such as cotton, and fluctuations in pricing structures.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	Prior to calendar year 2006, we sourced the majority of our finished products domestically.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	Today, the significant majority of our products are sourced internationally.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	During this same period, we began direct sourcing of our raw materials and brought management of logistics in-house.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P12_S3	These sourcing changes, along with better cost management, contributed to improvements in gross margin over this period.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	Gross margin measures gross profit as a percentage of our net revenues.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	A expenses include selling; advertising, marketing, and product development; and administrative.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	Selling expenses include Direct business expenses such as store expenses, employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs, as well as Indirect business expenses consisting primarily of employee compensation and other expenses associated with sales to Indirect retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S3	Advertising, marketing, and product development expenses include employee compensation, media costs, creative production expenses, marketing agency fees, new product design costs, public relations expenses, and market research expenses.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S4	A portion of our advertising expenses may be reimbursed by Indirect retailers, and such amount is classified as other income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S5	Administrative expenses include compensation costs for corporate functions, corporate headquarters occupancy costs, consulting and software expenses, and charitable donations.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S6	SG A expenses increase as the number of stores increases, but not in the same proportion as the associated increase in revenues.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S7	Other Income We support many of our Indirect retailers marketing efforts by distributing certain catalogs and promotional mailers to current and prospective customers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S8	Our Indirect retailers reimburse us for a portion of the cost to produce these materials.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S9	Reimbursement received is recorded as other income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S10	The related cost to design, produce, and distribute the catalogs and mailers is recorded as SG A expense.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S11	Other income also includes proceeds from the sales of tickets to our annual outlet sale and the gain on the sale of certain life insurance policies.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S12	Operating Income Operating income equals gross profit less SG A expenses plus other income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P13_S13	Operating income excludes interest income, interest expense, and income taxes.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	(subject to exception in a limited number of state and local jurisdictions that do not recognize the S Corporation status).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	On October 3, 2010, our S Corporation status automatically terminated and we became subject to corporate-level federal and state income taxes at prevailing corporate rates.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S1	Fiscal 2012 Compared to Fiscal 2011 Net Revenues For fiscal 2012, net revenues increased $94.8 million, or 26.0%, to $460.8 million, from $366.1 million for fiscal 2011, primarily due to increased volume.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S2	For fiscal 2012, net revenues increased $74.2 million, or 49.1%, to $225.3 million, from $151.1 million for fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S3	This growth resulted from a $28.6 million increase in e-commerce revenues due primarily to greater traffic resulting from marketing initiatives, a $39.4 million increase in non-comparable store sales, and a $6.2 million, or 10.9%, increase in comparable-store sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S4	The number of our stores grew from 39 at the end of fiscal 2011 to 56 at the end of fiscal 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S5	For fiscal 2012, net revenues increased $20.6 million, or 9.6%, to $235.6 million, from $214.9 million for fiscal 2011, due to increased sales volume to our specialty retailers, driven by strong demand for carryover patterns, fall product assortment, and the launch of rolling luggage.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S6	Gross Profit For fiscal 2012, gross profit increased $48.5 million, or 23.2%, to $257.6 million, from $209.1 million for fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S7	As a percentage of net revenues, gross profit decreased to 55.9% for fiscal 2012, from 57.1% for fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S8	The decrease in gross margin was due primarily to higher cotton and labor costs and higher sales of certain retired inventory sold at lower than normal gross margins, partially offset by an overall revenue mix shift toward higher margin, retail-store sales and e-commerce.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S9	For fiscal 2012, SG A expenses increased $6.3 million, or 3.9%, to $169.4 million, from $163.1 million for fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S10	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 36.8% and 44.5% for fiscal 2012 and fiscal 2011, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S11	The decrease as a percentage of net revenues in SG A expenses was due primarily to $21.9 million of compensation expense related to restricted-stock awards and a decline in professional fees related to our transition from a private to a public company both of which were included in fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P17_S12	In addition, SG A expenses declined as a percentage of net revenues due to leverage of our relatively fixed cost structure of the Indirect segment, partially offset by our investment into the Japanese market.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	Other Income For fiscal 2012, other income increased $0.8 million, or 10.4%, to $8.0 million, from $7.2 million for fiscal 2011, due primarily to increased reimbursement of our advertising expenses by our specialty retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	The increase was due in part to sales of tickets to our annual outlet sale and the gain on the sale of certain life insurance policies.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	Operating Income For fiscal 2012, operating income increased $42.9 million, or 80.4%, to $96.2 million, from $53.3 million for fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S3	As a percentage of net revenues, operating income was 20.9% and 14.6% for fiscal 2012 and fiscal 2011, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S4	This increase as a percentage of net revenues was due primarily to the $21.9 million of compensation expense related to restricted-stock awards in the prior year.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S5	Excluding this compensation expense in the prior year, operating income as a percentage of sales increased due to sales-driven leverage of SG A on our high growth of net revenues, partially offset by higher cotton and labor prices and our investment into the Japanese market (in thousands): Direct .
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S6	For fiscal 2012, operating income increased $21.7 million, or 46.6%, due to an increase in gross profit, offset in part by increased selling expenses related to store operational costs and costs associated with our market entry into Japan.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S7	For fiscal 2012, operating income increased $1.4 million, or 1.5%, primarily from an increase in revenue and sales-driven leverage of SG A, offset in part by a decline in gross margin, as previously discussed.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S8	For fiscal 2012, unallocated expenses decreased $19.8 million, or 23.4%, primarily as a result of stock-based compensation expense and bonuses paid to recipients of restricted-stock awards in the prior-year period.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S9	Interest Expense, Net For the fiscal year ended January 28, 2012, net interest expense decreased $0.5 million, or 29.5%, to $1.1 million, from $1.6 million in the fiscal year ended January 29, 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S10	The decrease of $0.5 million was due primarily to a write off in the same period of the prior-year of $0.2 million of unamortized debt-issuance costs in connection with the amendment and restatement of the credit agreement.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S11	The remaining $0.3 million was attributable to lower average borrowing rates in the fiscal year ended January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S12	Income Tax Expense For fiscal 2012, we recorded income tax expense of $37.1 million at an effective tax rate of 39.0%, which is consistent with U.S. federal and state statutory rates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S13	The change in our effective tax rate from fiscal 2011 reflects a more normalized rate due to being subject to corporate-level U.S. federal and state income taxes for the full fiscal year.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P18_S14	The effective tax rate also reflects a loss for the Japanese operations for which a tax benefit was not recognized.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	For fiscal 2011, we recorded income tax expense of $5.5 million.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	This expense was comprised of (1) $6.8 million of expense related to activity during the portion of fiscal 2011 that we were a C Corporation (October 3, 2010, through January 29, 2011) at an effective tax rate of 51.2% and (2) $0.5 million of state taxes related to taxing jurisdictions that did not recognize our previous S Corporation status, offset in part by a one-time deferred tax benefit of $1.8 million recognized upon the termination of our S Corporation status.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P19_S2	Included in tax expense for the portion of the fiscal year that we operated as a C Corporation was $1.2 million related to permanently non-deductible stock-based compensation expense associated with restricted-stock awards that vested in connection with our initial public offering.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Fiscal 2011 Compared to Fiscal 2010 Net Revenues For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $77.2 million, or 26.7%, to $366.1 million, from $288.9 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $22.1 million, or 11.5%, to $214.9 million, from $192.8 million for fiscal 2010, due primarily to increased sales volume to our Indirect retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S2	The increased sales volume resulted primarily from greater demand for our Signature Collection releases that, in most cases, had more patterns and styles relative to fiscal 2010 releases, increased offerings and sales of non-Signature Collection products, and improved economic conditions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S3	For fiscal 2011, net revenues increased $55.0 million, or 57.2%, to $151.1 million, from $96.1 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S4	This growth resulted from a $22.8 million increase in e-commerce revenues due primarily to greater traffic resulting from marketing initiatives, a $22.6 million increase in non-comparable store sales, and a $7.3 million, or 25.8%, increase in comparable-store sales due primarily to increased store traffic.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S5	The number of our stores grew from 27 at the end of fiscal 2010 to 39 at the end of fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S6	In addition, our annual outlet sale revenues increased by $2.3 million due to an increase in the number of shoppers that attended the sale and higher average product pricing at the sale.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S7	Gross Profit For fiscal 2011, gross profit increased $58.0 million, or 38.4%, to $209.1 million, from $151.1 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S8	As a percentage of net revenues, gross profit increased to 57.1% for fiscal 2011, from 52.3% for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P20_S9	The increase in gross margin was due primarily to increased leverage of fixed costs as a result of the volume growth, improved efficiency in our utilization of raw materials as a result of our expanding outlet store channel, higher average product pricing at the annual outlet sale, and an overall revenue mix shift toward higher margin, retail-store sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	For fiscal 2011, SG A expenses increased $46.9 million, or 40.4%, to $163.1 million, from $116.2 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 44.5% and 40.2% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S2	For fiscal 2011, selling expenses increased $19.9 million, or 36.0%, to $75.3 million, from $55.4 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S3	As a percentage of net revenues, selling expenses were 20.6% and 19.2% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S4	The increase in selling expenses was due primarily to increased store operational costs attributable to new store openings as well as e-commerce and store marketing initiatives to drive increased traffic.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S5	The increase in selling expenses also resulted from the company holding two product introduction and educational events (or Premieres) for Indirect retailers during fiscal 2011, compared to only one event during fiscal 2010, and from other increased expenses as a result of the increase in net revenues.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S6	These increases were partially offset by a $1.3 million asset-impairment charge, as further described below, recorded in fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P21_S7	No such charge was recorded in fiscal 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	For fiscal 2011, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses decreased $1.1 million, or 3.7%, to $28.7 million, from $29.8 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, advertising, marketing, and product development expenses were 7.8% and 10.3% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S2	This decrease resulted primarily from reduced expenses associated with our co-op marketing programs as a result of refining the marketing support for our Indirect retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S3	These reduced expenses were offset in part by increased spending on non-co-op advertising and marketing efforts and by higher employee and other costs associated with our expanded product design capabilities and with the increase in net revenues.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S4	For fiscal 2011, administrative expenses increased $28.1 million, or 90.7%, to $59.0 million, from $30.9 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S5	As a percentage of net revenues, administrative expenses were 16.1% and 10.7% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S6	This increase was due primarily to $15.8 million of stock-based compensation expense associated with the vesting of restricted-stock awards in connection with our initial public offering as well as $6.1 million of expense associated with bonuses paid to recipients of the restricted-stock awards to satisfy tax obligations.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S7	In addition, we incurred higher corporate personnel and other costs necessary to support our growth as well as increased professional services fees related in part to our transition from a private to a public company.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S8	Other Income For fiscal 2012, other income decreased $3.5 million, or 32.7%, to $7.2 million, from $10.7 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P22_S9	This decrease was due to the above-discussed refinement of the marketing support for our Indirect retailers, which resulted in decreased reimbursement of our advertising expenses.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	Operating Income For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $7.6 million, or 16.6%, to $53.3 million, from $45.7 million for fiscal 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, operating income was 14.6% and 15.8% for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S2	This decrease in operating income as a percentage of net revenues was due primarily to the previously discussed $15.8 million of stock-based compensation expense associated with the vesting of restricted-stock awards in connection with our initial public offering and the $6.1 million of expense associated with bonuses paid to recipients of the restricted-stock awards.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S3	Operating income for our business segments is provided below.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S4	Indirect For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $19.1 million, or 26.2%, primarily as a result of the previously discussed increase in gross profit.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S5	This increase was partially offset by increased selling expenses, as previously discussed.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S6	For fiscal 2011, operating income increased $21.1 million, or 83.7%, primarily as a result of the previously discussed increase in gross profit.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P23_S7	This increase was partially offset by increased selling expenses, as previously discussed.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	For fiscal 2011, unallocated expenses increased $32.6 million, or 62.4%, primarily as a result of increased stock-based and bonus compensation expenses, higher corporate personnel and other costs, and increased professional services fees, as previously discussed.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	Interest Expense, Net Net interest expense was consistent for fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010; a $0.2 million write off of unamortized debt-issuance costs in connection with the amendment and restatement of our credit agreement was offset by lower average borrowing levels during fiscal 2011.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S3	This expense was comprised of (1) $6.8 million of expense related to activity during the portion of fiscal 2011 that we were a C Corporation (October 3, 2010, through January 29, 2011) at an effective tax rate of 51.2% and (2) $0.5 million of state taxes related to taxing jurisdictions that did not recognize our previous S Corporation status, offset in part by a one-time deferred tax benefit of $1.8 million recognized upon the termination of our S Corporation status.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S4	Included in tax expense for the portion of the fiscal year that we operated as a C Corporation was $1.2 million related to permanently non-deductible stock-based compensation expense associated with restricted-stock awards that vested in connection with our initial public offering.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S5	For fiscal 2010, our income tax expense of $0.9 million (calculated at an effective rate of 2.0%) was comprised solely of state taxes related to taxing jurisdictions that did not recognize our previous S Corporation status.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P24_S6	The increase in our effective tax rate resulted from our change in tax status.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources General Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	We also have access to additional liquidity, if needed, through borrowings under our $125.0 million amended and restated credit agreement.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Historically, our primary cash needs have been for merchandise inventories, payroll, store rent, capital expenditures associated with opening new stores, debt repayments, operational equipment, and information technology.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P26_S1	The most significant components of our working capital are cash and cash equivalents, merchandise inventories, accounts receivable, accounts payable, and other current liabilities.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P26_S2	We do not believe that the expansion of our Direct business will materially alter the nature and levels of our accounts receivable and inventories, or require materially increased borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement, in the near term.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P26_S3	We believe that cash flows from operating activities and the availability of borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement or other financing arrangements will be sufficient to meet working capital requirements, anticipated capital expenditures, and debt payments for the foreseeable future.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	Amended and Restated Credit Agreement On October 4, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. entered into an agreement to amend and restate its credit agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, as administrative agent, and certain other lenders.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S1	The amended and restated credit agreement provides for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million and matures on October 3, 2015.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S2	All borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement are collateralized by substantially all of the Company s assets.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S3	The credit agreement is also guaranteed by the Company.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S4	The credit agreement requires the Company to comply with various financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.20 to 1.00 and a leverage ratio of not more than 3.50 to 1.00.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S5	The agreement also contains various other covenants, including restrictions on the incurrence of certain indebtedness, liens, investments, acquisitions, and asset sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P29_S6	The Company was in compliance with these covenants as of January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	Borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement bear interest at either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	The applicable margin is tied to the Company s leverage ratio.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P30_S2	In addition, the Company is required to pay a quarterly facility fee (as defined in the agreement) ranging from 0.20% to 0.45% of the revolving credit commitment.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P30_S3	At January 28, 2012, the weighted-average interest rate on the $25.0 million of outstanding borrowings under the credit agreement was 1.68%.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P30_S4	The Company had borrowing availability of $100.0 million under the agreement as of January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	We enter into long-term contractual obligations and commitments in the normal course of business, primarily debt obligations and non-cancellable operating leases.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of our assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	We evaluate our accounting policies, estimates, and judgments on an on-going basis.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P38_S2	We base our estimates and judgments on historical experience and various other factors that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P38_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions and conditions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P38_S4	We evaluate the development and selection of our critical accounting policies and estimates and believe that the following policies and estimates involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity and are most significant to reporting our results of operations and financial position, and are therefore discussed as critical.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	The following critical accounting policies reflect the significant estimates and judgments used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	With respect to critical accounting policies, even a relatively minor variance between actual and expected experience can potentially have a materially favorable or unfavorable impact on subsequent results of operations.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P40_S1	Our historical results for the periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, however, have not been materially impacted by such variances.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P40_S2	More information on all of our significant accounting policies can be found in Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from the sale of our products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an estimate of shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P41_S1	The estimate of these shipments is based on shipping terms and historical delivery times.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P41_S2	Significant changes in shipping terms or delivery times could materially impact our revenues in a given period.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P42_S0	We reserve for projected merchandise returns based on historical experience and other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	Merchandise returns are often resalable merchandise and in the Direct business are refunded by issuing the same payment tender of the original purchase and in the Indirect business the customer is issued a credit to its account to apply to outstanding invoices.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	Merchandise exchanges of the same product at the same price are not considered merchandise returns.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S2	Product returns are often resalable through our annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S3	Additionally, we reserve for other potential product credits and for customer shipments not yet received.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S4	The total reserve for returns, customer shipments not yet received, and general credits was $2.6 million and $1.7 million at January 28, 2012, and January 29, 2011, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P43_S5	This represents a reduction to operating income of $1.8 million and $1.2 million, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P44_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P44_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P44_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	We record valuation adjustments to our inventories, which are reflected in cost of sales, if the cost of specific inventory items on hand exceeds the amount we expect to realize from the ultimate sale or disposal of the inventory.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	and inventory levels, including sell-through of remaining units.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S1	In addition, as part of inventory adjustments, we provide for inventory shrinkage based on historical trends from our physical inventory counts.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S2	We perform physical inventory counts throughout the year and adjust the shrink provision accordingly.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S3	Inventory adjustments of $3.3 million and $5.1 million were recorded for these matters as of January 28, 2012, and January 29, 2011, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S4	These adjustments related primarily to raw materials of discontinued patterns, as we have the ability to move discontinued finished goods through a number of channels, including the annual outlet sale, our website and outlet stores, and through liquidators as needed.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P46_S5	The decrease in the valuation adjustments during fiscal 2012 resulted primarily from our expanding outlet store channel, which we launched in November 2009 which has enabled us to increase our use of raw materials of discontinued patterns as well as an improved cycle counting process resulting in less shrink.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	Income Taxes Prior to October 3, 2010, we were taxed as an S Corporation for federal income tax purposes under Section 1362 of the Internal Revenue Code, and therefore were not subject to federal and state income taxes (subject to exception in a limited number of state and local jurisdictions that do not recognize the S Corporation status).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	On October 3, 2010, our S Corporation status automatically terminated and we became subject to corporate-level federal and state income taxes at prevailing corporate rates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	Our effective tax rate is based on our pre-tax income, statutory tax rates, tax laws and regulations, and tax planning opportunities available in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P47_S3	Significant judgment is required in determining our annual tax expense and in evaluating our tax positions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P47_S4	We establish reserves to remove some or all of the tax benefit of any of our tax positions at the time we determine that the positions become uncertain based upon one of the following: (1) the tax position is not more likely than not to be sustained; (2) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but for a lesser amount; or (3) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but not in the financial period in which the tax position was originally taken.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	Taxing authorities periodically audit our income tax returns.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P48_S1	We believe that our tax filing positions are reasonable and legally supportable.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P48_S2	Taxing authorities, however, may take a contrary position.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P48_S3	Our results of operations and effective tax rate in a given period could be impacted if, upon final resolution with taxing authorities, we prevail in positions for which we have established reserves, or are required to pay amounts in excess of established reserves.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	Valuation of Long-lived Assets Property, plant, and equipment assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	In evaluating an asset for recoverability, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset at the store level, the lowest identifiable level of cash flow, if applicable.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	If the sum of the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the asset is less than the carrying value, we recognize a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, usually determined by an estimated discounted cash flow analysis of the asset.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	Factors used in the valuation of long-lived assets include, but are not limited to, our plans for future operations, brand initiatives, recent operating results, and projected future cash flows.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	With respect to our stores, we analyze store economics, location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies in our selection process.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	Impairment charges are classified in SG A expenses.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	The discounted cash flow models used to estimate the applicable fair values involve numerous estimates and assumptions that are highly subjective.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	Changes to these estimates and assumptions could materially impact the fair value estimates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P54_S2	The estimates and assumptions critical to the overall fair value estimates include: (1) estimated future cash flow generated at the store level; and (2) discount rates used to derive the present value factors used in determining the fair values.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P54_S3	These and other estimates and assumptions are impacted by economic conditions and our expectations and may change in the future based on period-specific facts and circumstances.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P54_S4	If economic conditions were to deteriorate, future impairment charges may be required.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements In June 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2011-05, Comprehensive Income Presentation of Comprehensive Income .
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	This guidance eliminates the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the Statement of Shareholders Equity.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S2	Instead, the Company must report comprehensive income in either a single continuous statement of comprehensive income which contains two sections, net income and other comprehensive income, or in two separate but consecutive statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S3	While the new guidance changes the presentation of comprehensive income, there are no changes to the components that are recognized in net income or other comprehensive income under current accounting guidance.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S4	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S5	As this guidance only amends the presentation of the components of comprehensive income, the adoption will not have an impact on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S6	Early adoption is permitted, but full retrospective application is required under both sets of accounting standards.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P55_S7	The guidance also previously required the presentation of adjustments for items that are reclassified from other comprehensive income to net income in the statement where the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income are presented; however, this portion of the guidance has been deferred through an ASU issued in September 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	Upon adoption, the Company will elect to present items of net income and other comprehensive income in one continuous statement, the statement of comprehensive income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	In May 2011, the FASB issued ASU 2011-4, Fair Value Measurement Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and IFRS .
1495320_12_ITEM7_P57_S1	The guidance requires additional disclosures, including disclosures related to the measurement of level 3 assets.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P57_S2	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011 and is applied prospectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P57_S3	The Company is currently evaluating this guidance, but does not expect its adoption will have a material effect on its consolidated financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	Transactions with Related Parties See Item 13, Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, and Director Independence, of this report for information regarding transactions with related parties.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk Interest Rate Risk We are subject to interest rate risk in connection with borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement, which bear interest at variable rates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	The amended and restated credit agreement allows for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million, bearing interest at a variable rate, based on either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	Assuming the amended and restated credit agreement is fully drawn, each quarter point increase or decrease in the interest rate would change our annual interest expense by approximately $0.3 million.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	From time to time, we utilize interest rate swaps to hedge our interest rate risk.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	We had no open derivative instruments at January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	Impact of Inflation Our results of operations and financial condition are presented based on historical cost.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	Although it is difficult to accurately measure the impact of inflation due to the imprecise nature of the estimates required, we believe the effects of inflation, if any, on our results of operations and financial condition have been immaterial.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Foreign Exchange Rate Risk We source a substantial majority of our materials from various suppliers in China and South Korea.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	Substantially all purchases and sales involving foreign persons are denominated in U.S. dollars, and therefore we do not hedge using any derivative instruments.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	Historically, we have not been impacted materially by changes in exchange rates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm To the Board of Directors and Shareholders of Vera Bradley, Inc.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements listed in the accompanying index present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Vera Bradley, Inc. and its subsidiaries at January 28, 2012 and January 29, 2011, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended January 28, 2012 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 28, 2012, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S3	The Company s management is responsible for these financial statements, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting appearing under Item 9A.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S4	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements and on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audits (which was an integrated audit in 2012).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S7	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P65_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P66_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P66_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	Description of the Company Vera Bradley, Inc. was formed as an Indiana corporation on June 23, 2010, for the purpose of reorganizing the corporate structure of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	On October 3, 2010, the shareholders of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. contributed all of their shares of Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock of Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. to Vera Bradley, Inc. in return for shares of Vera Bradley, Inc.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S2	Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock on a one-for-one basis.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S3	In addition, effective October 3, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. converted from an S Corporation to a C Corporation for income-tax purposes.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S4	Further, on October 18, 2010, Vera Bradley, Inc. recapitalized all of its Class A Voting Common Stock and Class B Non-Voting Common Stock into a single class of common stock and effectuated a 35.437-for-1 stock split of all outstanding shares of its common stock.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S5	These events collectively are referred to as the Reorganization.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S6	As a result of the Reorganization, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. became a wholly owned subsidiary of Vera Bradley, Inc.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S7	Except where context requires or where otherwise indicated, the terms Company and Vera Bradley refer to Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. and its subsidiaries before the Reorganization and to Vera Bradley, Inc. and its subsidiaries, including Vera Bradley Designs, Inc., after the Reorganization.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P71_S8	All historical common stock and per share common stock information has been changed to reflect the stock split.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish, highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	The Company s products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	The Company generates net revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P72_S3	The Direct business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products through the Company s full-price stores, outlet stores, verabradley.com, and an annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P72_S4	As of January 28, 2012, the Company operated 48 full-price stores and eight outlet stores in the United States, seven pop-up stores in Japan, our websites, verabradley.com and verabradley.co.jp, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	The Indirect business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,300 specialty retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as select national retailers and third-party e-commerce sites.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S1	The Company has eliminated intercompany balances and transactions in consolidation.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S2	The Company s fiscal year ends on the Saturday closest to January 31.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S3	Unaudited Pro Forma Income Information Prior to the Reorganization, the Company was taxed as an S Corporation for purposes of federal and state income taxes.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S4	Accordingly, each of the Company s then-shareholders was required to include his or her portion of the Company s taxable income or loss on his or her federal and state income tax returns.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S5	As part of the Reorganization, effective October 3, 2010, the Company s S Corporation status automatically terminated and the Company became subject to corporate-level federal and state income taxes at prevailing corporate rates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S6	The unaudited pro forma income information gives effect to an adjustment for income tax expense as if the Company had been a C Corporation at the beginning of each period presented at an assumed combined federal, state, and local income tax rate of 41.7% for the period from January 31, 2010, through October 2, 2010, and 40% for the fiscal year ended January 30, 2010.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P74_S7	These rates approximate the calculated effective tax rates for the periods presented.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of the Company s assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P75_S1	Significant areas requiring the use of management estimates include the valuation of inventories, accounts receivable valuation allowances, sales return allowances, and the useful lives of assets for depreciation or amortization.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P75_S2	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P75_S3	The Company revises its estimates and assumptions as new information becomes available.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents represent cash on hand, deposits with financial institutions, and investments with an original maturity of three months or less.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	Restricted Cash At January 30, 2010, the Company maintained $1.5 million in an account with one of its lenders as a compensating balance in connection with the credit agreement entered into during the fiscal year ended January 31, 2009.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	In October 2010, as part of the amendment and restatement of the Company s credit agreement (see Note 5), this compensating-balance requirement was eliminated.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P76_S3	Concentration of Credit Risk The Company maintains nearly all of its cash and cash equivalents with one financial institution.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P76_S4	The Company monitors the credit standing of this financial institution on a regular basis.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P77_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P77_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P77_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	Property, Plant, and Equipment Property, plant, and equipment are carried at cost and depreciated or amortized over the following estimated useful lives using the straight-line method:
1495320_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the life of the asset or the lease term.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P79_S1	Lease terms typically range from five to ten years.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	When a decision is made to abandon property, plant, and equipment prior to the end of the previously estimated useful life, depreciation or amortization estimates are revised to reflect the use of the asset over the shortened estimated useful life.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P80_S1	At the time of disposal, the cost of assets sold or retired and the related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts and any resulting loss is included in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	Property, plant, and equipment are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be recoverable.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	The reviews are conducted at the lowest identifiable level of cash flows.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	If the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the property, plant, and equipment are less than the carrying value, the Company recognizes a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, as further defined below in Fair Value of Financial Instruments.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	Routine maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs incurred in connection with acquiring, modifying, and installing internal-use software.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P84_S1	Capitalized costs are included in property, plant, and equipment and are amortized over three to five years.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P84_S2	Software costs that do not meet capitalization criteria are expensed as incurred.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	Revenue Recognition and Accounts Receivable Revenue from the sale of the Company s products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an estimate of shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P85_S1	The estimate of these shipments is based on shipping terms and historical delivery times.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	Included in net revenues are product sales to Direct and Indirect customers, including amounts billed to customers for shipping fees.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	Costs related to shipping of product are classified in cost of sales in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	Net revenues exclude sales taxes collected from customers and remitted to governmental authorities.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	Historical experience provides the Company the ability to estimate reasonably the amount of product sales that customers will return.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	Product returns are often resalable through the Company s annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P87_S2	The Company accounts for anticipated returns by reducing net revenues, cost of sales, and accounts receivable and increasing inventories, essentially reversing the effects of the original sales transactions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P87_S3	Additionally, the Company reserves for other potential product credits granted to Indirect retailers.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P87_S4	The returns and credits reserve and the related activity for each fiscal year presented were as follows (in thousands):
1495320_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company establishes an allowance for doubtful accounts based on historical experience and customer-specific identification and believes that collections of receivables, net of the allowance for doubtful accounts, are reasonably assured.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P88_S1	The allowance for doubtful accounts was approximately $0.6 million and $0.3 million at January 28, 2012, and January 29, 2011, respectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	Cost of Sales Cost of sales includes material and labor costs, freight, inventory shrinkage, operating lease costs, duty, and other operating expenses, including depreciation of the Company s distribution center, warehouse and manufacturing facilities, and equipment.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	Costs and related expenses to manufacture and distribute the products are recorded as cost of sales when the related revenues are recognized.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	The Company has leases that contain rent holidays and predetermined, fixed escalations of minimum rentals.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P90_S1	For each of these leases, the Company recognizes the related rent expense on a straight-line basis commencing on the date of initial possession of the leased property.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P90_S2	The Company records the difference between the recognized rent expense and the amount payable under the lease as a deferred lease credit.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	The Company receives tenant-improvement allowances from some of the landlords of its leased properties.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P91_S1	These allowances generally are in the form of cash received by the Company from its landlords as part of the negotiated lease terms.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P91_S2	The Company records each tenant-improvement allowance as a deferred credit and amortizes the allowance on a straight-line basis as a reduction to rent expense over the term of the lease, commencing on the possession date.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	The Company charges costs associated with the opening of new stores to selling, general, and administrative expenses as incurred.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P92_S1	Selling, general, and administrative expenses also include store operating costs, store employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	Stock-Based Compensation The Company accounts for stock-based compensation using the fair-value recognition provisions of ASC 718, Stock Compensation.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	Under these provisions, for its awards of restricted stock and restricted-stock units, the Company recognizes stock-based compensation expense in an amount equal to the fair market value of the underlying stock on the grant date of the respective award.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S2	The Company recognizes this expense, net of estimated forfeitures, on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S3	For restricted-stock awards granted prior to its initial public offering, the Company recognized stock-based compensation expense over the period the restrictions were to lapse and, then, in full upon the initial public offering.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S4	Other Income and Advertising Costs The Company expenses advertising costs at the time the promotion first appears in media, in stores, or on the website, and includes those costs in selling, general, and administrative expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P93_S5	The Company classifies the related recovery of a portion of such costs from Indirect retailers as other income in the Consolidated Statements of Income.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value are classified using the following hierarchy, which is based upon the transparency of inputs to the valuation as of the measurement date:
1495320_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	The classification of fair value measurements within the hierarchy is based upon the lowest level of input that is significant to the measurement.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	Income Taxes The Company accounts for income taxes and the related accounts using the liability method in accordance with ASC 740, Income Taxes.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P101_S1	Under this method, the Company accrues income taxes payable or refundable and recognizes deferred tax assets and liabilities based on differences between the GAAP and tax bases of assets and liabilities.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P101_S2	The Company measures deferred tax assets and liabilities using enacted rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse, and recognizes the effect of a change in enacted rates in the period of enactment.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P101_S3	The Company establishes assets and liabilities for uncertain positions taken or expected to be taken in income tax returns, using a more-likely-than-not recognition threshold.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P101_S4	The Company includes in income tax expense any interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements In June 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2011-05, Comprehensive Income Presentation of Comprehensive Income .
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S1	This guidance eliminates the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the Statement of Shareholders Equity.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S2	Instead, the Company must report comprehensive income in either a single continuous statement of comprehensive income which contains two sections, net income and other comprehensive income, or in two separate but consecutive statements.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S3	While the new guidance changes the presentation of comprehensive income, there are no changes to the components that are recognized in net income or other comprehensive income under current accounting guidance.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S4	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S5	As this guidance only amends the presentation of the components of comprehensive income, the adoption will not have an impact on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S6	Early adoption is permitted, but full retrospective application is required under both sets of accounting standards.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P102_S7	The guidance also previously required the presentation of adjustments for items that are reclassified from other comprehensive income to net income in the statement where the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income are presented; however, this portion of the guidance has been deferred through an ASU issued in September 2011.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	Upon adoption, the Company will elect to present items of net income and other comprehensive income in one continuous statement, the statement of comprehensive income.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P104_S0	In May 2011, the FASB issued ASU 2011-4, Fair Value Measurement Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and IFRS .
1495320_12_ITEM7_P104_S1	The guidance requires additional disclosures, including disclosures related to the measurement of level 3 assets.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P104_S2	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011 and is applied prospectively.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P104_S3	The Company is currently evaluating this guidance, but does not expect its adoption will have a material effect on its consolidated financial statements.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S0	Credit Agreement On October 4, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. entered into an agreement to amend and restate its credit agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, as administrative agent, and certain other lenders.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S1	The amended and restated credit agreement provides for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million and matures on October 3, 2015.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S2	All borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement are collateralized by substantially all of the Company s assets.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S3	The credit agreement is also guaranteed by the Company.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S4	The credit agreement requires the Company to comply with various financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.20 to 1.00 and a leverage ratio of not more than 3.50 to 1.00.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S5	The agreement also contains various other covenants, including restrictions on the incurrence of certain indebtedness, liens, investments, acquisitions, and asset sales.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P111_S6	The Company was in compliance with these covenants as of January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P112_S0	Borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement bear interest at either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_12_ITEM7_P112_S1	The applicable margin is tied to the Company s leverage ratio.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P112_S2	In addition, the Company is required to pay a quarterly facility fee (as defined in the agreement) ranging from 0.20% to 0.45% of the revolving credit commitment.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P112_S3	At January 28, 2012, the interest rate on the $25.0 million of outstanding borrowings under the credit agreement was 1.36%.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P112_S4	The Company had borrowing availability of $100.0 million under the agreement as of January 28, 2012.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P142_S0	The Company has two operating segments, which are also its reportable segments, Indirect and Direct.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P142_S1	These operating segments are components of the Company for which separate financial information is available and for which operating results are evaluated on a regular basis by the chief operating decision maker in deciding how to allocate resources and in assessing the performance of the segments.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P143_S0	The Indirect segment represents revenues generated through the distribution of Company-branded products to approximately 3,300 specialty Indirect retailers across the United States.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P143_S1	The Direct segment includes the Company s full-price and outlet stores, e-commerce activity driven by the Company s website, and the annual outlet sale.
1495320_12_ITEM7_P143_S2	Revenues generated through this segment are driven through the sale of Company-branded products from Vera Bradley to end consumers.

1495320_12_ITEM7_P144_S1	All intercompany-related activities are eliminated in consolidation and are excluded from the segment reporting.

Blade, the Chief Financial and Administrative Officer of the Company, has concluded that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures are effective as of January 28, 2012.
1495320_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as defined in rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act.
1495320_12_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external reporting purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.

1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish and highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	Our products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	Over our 30-year history, Vera Bradley has become a true lifestyle brand that appeals to a broad range of consumers.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our brand vision is accessible luxury that inspires a casual, fun, and family-oriented lifestyle.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S4	Our brand positioning emphasizes the high quality, distinctive and vibrant styling, and functional design of our products.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P0_S5	Frequent releases of new designs help keep the brand fresh and our customers continually engaged.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	We generate net revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	As of February 2, 2013, our Direct segment consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products through our 65 full-price and 11 outlet stores in the United States; 15 department store locations in Japan; our websites, verabradley.com and verabradley.co.jp; and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P1_S2	As of February 2, 2013, our Indirect segment consisted of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,400 specialty retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as select department stores and third party e-commerce sites.
1495320_13_ITEM1_P1_S3	For financial information about our reportable segments, refer to Note 14 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Part II, Item 8.
