1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	Fiscal 2014 Compared to Fiscal 2013 Net Revenues For fiscal 2014 , net revenues decreased $5.1 million, or 0.9%, to $536.0 million, from $541.1 million for fiscal 2013 , primarily due to an additional 7 days included in fiscal 2013 compared to fiscal 2014, which added net revenues of $4.9 million and decreased volume.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	For fiscal 2014 , net revenues increased $33.7 million, or 11.5%, to $326.2 million, from $292.6 million for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S2	This growth resulted primarily from a $31.0 million increase in revenues at our stores due to 23 additional full-price and outlet stores which is offset by a comparable-store sales decrease of $8.4 million, or 5.7%.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S3	The decreases in comparable store and e-commerce sales related to year-over-year declines in traffic, a lower average transaction size, and underperformance of the product offering.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S4	The number of our stores grew from 76 at the end of fiscal 2013 to 99 at the end of fiscal 2014 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P20_S5	For fiscal 2014 , net revenues decreased $38.8 million, or 15.6%, to $209.8 million, from $248.6 million for fiscal 2013 , primarily due to lower orders from the Company s specialty retailers combined with closing approximately 400 wholesale accounts during the year, through a combination of remediation, natural attrition, and a more selective approach to opening new specialty gift stores.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	Gross Profit For fiscal 2014 , gross profit decreased $12.8 million, or 4.2%, to $295.4 million, from $308.3 million for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	As a percentage of net revenues, gross profit decreased to 55.1% for fiscal 2014, from 57.0% for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	The decrease in gross margin was due primarily to a $4.8 million i nventory write-down, increased year-over-year promotional activity, as well as the sales mix of lower-margin product.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S3	For fiscal 2014 , SG A expenses increased $1.5 million, or 0.8%, to $206.0 million, from $204.4 million for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S4	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 38.4% and 37.8% for fiscal 2014 and fiscal 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S5	The increase in SG A expenses as a percent of net revenues was primarily due to fixed expenses being spread over lower revenues in the Indirect segment, the deleveraging of store operating expenses, and the impact of employee-related expenses from headcount added in the first half of fiscal 2014, partially offset by reductions in variable compensation expense associated with Company performance.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S6	Other Income For fiscal 2014 , other income decreased $1.5 million, or 23.9%, to $4.8 million, from $6.3 million for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S7	The decrease in other income was in line with a decrease in associated advertising costs related to mailers for our specialty retailers.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S8	Operating Income For fiscal 2014 , operating income decreased $15.9 million, or 14.4%, to $94.3 million, from $110.1 million for fiscal 2013 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S9	As a percentage of net revenues, operating income was 17.6% and 20.4% for fiscal 2014 and fiscal 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P21_S10	The following table provides additional information about our operating income (in thousands).
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	For fiscal 2014 , operating income decreased $5.2 million, or 6.1%.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	As a percentage of Direct segment net revenues, operating income in the Direct segment was 24.5% and 29.1% for fiscal 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	This decrease as a percentage of net revenues in the Direct segment was primarily due to sales of lower-margin product accounting for a higher percentage of total segment revenue, as well as increased promotional activity.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S3	For fiscal 2014 , operating income decreased $16.9 million, or 16.8%.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S4	As a percentage of Indirect segment net revenues, operating income in the Indirect segment was 40.1% and 40.7% for fiscal 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S5	This decrease as a percentage of net revenues in the Indirect segment resulted primarily from deleveraging of the relatively fixed SG A expenses against sales declines.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P22_S6	For fiscal 2014 , unallocated expenses decreased $6.2 million, or 8.2%, primarily as a result of discretionary spending cuts and reductions in variable compensation expense associated with the Company s financial performance.

1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	Fiscal 2013 Compared to Fiscal 2012 Net Revenues For fiscal 2013, net revenues increased $80.3 million, or 17.4%, to $541.1 million, from $460.8 million for fiscal 2012, primarily due to increased volume and an additional 7 days included in fiscal 2013 compared to fiscal 2012, which added net revenues of $4.9 million.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S1	For fiscal 2013, net revenues increased $67.3 million, or 29.9%, to $292.6 million, from $225.3 million for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S2	This growth resulted primarily from a $44.8 million increase in revenues related to additional full-price and outlet stores; a comparable-store sales increase of $3.4 million, or 3.4%, primarily driven by the improved performance of the product assortment and various in-store events to drive traffic; and an $18.9 million increase in e-commerce revenues due to the continued growth in website traffic.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S3	The number of our stores grew from 56 at the end of fiscal 2012 to 76 at the end of fiscal 2013.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S4	For fiscal 2013, net revenues increased $13.0 million, or 5.5%, to $248.6 million, from $235.6 million for fiscal 2012, due to growth in the number of department store locations and increased sales volume to our specialty retailers.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S5	Gross Profit For fiscal 2013, gross profit increased $50.7 million, or 19.7%, to $308.3 million, from $257.6 million for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S6	As a percentage of net revenues, gross profit increased to 57.0% for fiscal 2013, from 55.9% for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S7	The increase in gross margin was due primarily to operational efficiencies, lower freight expense, positive channel mix, and lower input costs.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S8	For fiscal 2013, SG A expenses increased $35.0 million, or 20.6%, to $204.4 million, from $169.4 million for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S9	As a percentage of net revenues, SG A expenses were 37.8% and 36.8% for fiscal 2013 and fiscal 2012, respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S10	The increase as a percentage of net revenues in SG A expenses was due primarily to increased headcount expenses and increased store operating expenses.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S11	Other Income For fiscal 2013, other income decreased $1.7 million, or 21.3%, to $6.3 million, from $8.0 million for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S12	The decrease in other income was in line with a decrease in associated advertising costs related to mailers for our specialty retailers.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S13	Operating Income For fiscal 2013, operating income increased $14.0 million, or 14.5%, to $110.1 million, from $96.2 million for fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P24_S14	As a percentage of net revenues, operating income was 20.4% and 20.9% for fiscal 2013 and fiscal 2012, respectively (in thousands).
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	For fiscal 2013, operating income increased $17.0 million, or 24.9%.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S1	As a percentage of Direct segment net revenues, operating income in the Direct segment was 29.1% and 30.2% for fiscals 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S2	This decrease as a percentage of net revenues in the Direct segment was primarily due to increased store operating expense.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S3	For fiscal 2013, operating income increased $8.0 million, or 8.6%.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S4	As a percentage of Indirect segment net revenues, operating income in the Indirect segment was 40.7% and 39.5% for fiscals 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P25_S5	This increase as a percentage of net revenues in the Indirect segment resulted primarily due to leverage of the relatively fixed SG A expenses, against sales growth.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	For fiscal 2013, unallocated expenses increased $11.0 million, or 16.9%, primarily as a result of increased corporate personnel and marketing costs.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	For fiscal 2013, net interest expense decreased $0.5 million, or 40.8%, to $0.7 million, from $1.1 million in fiscal 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	The decrease was due to lower average borrowing levels in fiscal 2013.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	For fiscal 2013, we recorded income tax expense of $40.6 million at an effective tax rate of 37.1%, compared to 39.0% for fiscal year 2012.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	The effective tax rate reduction was primarily related to state income tax credits associated with the completion of our distribution center expansion and discrete items recorded primarily during the third quarter.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	The impact of these items on the effective tax rate was approximately 1.2% for the fiscal year.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P27_S3	During fiscal 2012, there were other permanent items that caused a higher rate which did not recur during fiscal 2013 causing the rate to decrease approximately 0.5% compared to the prior year.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P27_S4	The effective tax rate also reflects a loss for the Japanese operations for which a tax benefit was not recognized.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources General Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	We also have access to additional liquidity, if needed, through borrowings under our $125.0 million amended and restated credit agreement.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	Historically, our primary cash needs have been for purchasing inventories, payroll, store rent, capital expenditures associated with opening new stores, buildings, operational equipment, information technology, and debt repayments.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P29_S1	The most significant components of our working capital are cash and cash equivalents, purchasing inventories, accounts receivable, accounts payable, and other current liabilities.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P29_S2	We do not believe that the expansion of our Direct business will materially increase borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement, in the near term.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P29_S3	We believe that cash flows from operating activities and the availability of borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement or other financing arrangements will be sufficient to meet working capital requirements and anticipated capital expenditures for the foreseeable future.

1495320_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	Net cash provided by operating activities increased to $87.9 million during fiscal 2014 , as compared to $51.5 million during fiscal 2013.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	This increase in cash provided by operating activities was primarily driven by a net working capital increase of $44.5 million, as a result of a reduced inventory build of $19.4 million along with an increase in accounts payable of $25.3 million.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P30_S3	This increase was partially offset by a decrease in net income of $10.1 million.

1495320_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	Amended and Restated Credit Agreement On October 4, 2010, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. entered into an agreement to amend and restate our credit agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, as administrative agent, and certain other lenders.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	The amended and restated credit agreement provides for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million and was to mature on October 3, 2015.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	On June 1, 2012, Vera Bradley Designs, Inc. entered into an amendment to the credit agreement.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	The amendment extends the maturity date from October 3, 2015 to June 1, 2017.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S2	Certain permitted indebtedness covenants were also amended.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S3	All borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement are collateralized by substantially all of the assets of Vera Bradley Design, Inc.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S4	The credit agreement is also guaranteed by the Company.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S5	The credit agreement requires us to comply with various financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.20 to 1.00 and a leverage ratio of not more than 3.50 to 1.00.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S6	The agreement also contains various other covenants, including restrictions on the incurrence of certain indebtedness, liens, investments, acquisitions, and asset sales.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P34_S7	We were in compliance with these covenants as of February 1, 2014 .
1495320_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	Borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement bear interest at either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	The applicable margin is tied to our leverage ratio.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	In addition, we are required to pay a quarterly facility fee (as defined in the agreement) ranging from 0.20% to 0.45% of the revolving credit commitment.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	We had borrowing availability of $125.0 million under the agreement as of February 1, 2014.

1495320_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of our assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	We evaluate our accounting policies, estimates, and judgments on an on-going basis.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	We base our estimates and judgments on historical experience and various other factors that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions and conditions.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P40_S4	We evaluate the development and selection of our critical accounting policies and estimates and believe that the following policies and estimates involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity and are most significant to reporting our results of operations and financial position, and are therefore discussed as critical.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	The following critical accounting policies reflect the significant estimates and judgments used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	With respect to critical accounting policies, even a relatively minor variance between actual and expected experience can potentially have a materially favorable or unfavorable impact on subsequent results of operations.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	Our historical results for the periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, however, have not been materially impacted by such variances.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	More information on all of our significant accounting policies can be found in Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from the sale of our products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an estimate of shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	The adjustment of these shipments is based on actual delivery dates to the customer.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P43_S2	Significant changes in shipping terms or delivery times could materially impact our revenues in a given period.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	We reserve for projected merchandise returns based on historical experience and other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	In the Direct business returns are refunded by issuing the same payment tender of the original purchase and in the Indirect business the customer is issued a credit to its account to apply to outstanding invoices.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	Merchandise exchanges of the same product at the same price are not considered merchandise returns.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	Product returns are often resalable through our annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	Additionally, we reserve for other potential product credits and for customer shipments not yet received.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P45_S3	The total reserve for returns, customer shipments not yet received, and general credits was $3.7 million and $4.1 million at February 1, 2014 , and February 2, 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P46_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P46_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	We record valuation adjustments to our inventories, which are reflected in cost of sales, if the cost of specific inventory items on hand exceeds the amount we expect to realize from the ultimate sale or disposal of the inventory.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	This adjustment calculation requires us to make assumptions and estimates, which are based on factors such as merchandise seasonality, historical trends, and estimated sales and inventory levels, including sell-through of remaining units.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	In addition, as part of inventory adjustments, we provide for inventory shrinkage based on historical trends from our physical inventory counts.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S3	We perform physical inventory counts throughout the year and adjust the shrink provision accordingly.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S4	Inventory adjustments of $8.9 million and $3.5 million were recorded for these matters as of the fiscal years ended February 1, 2014 , and February 2, 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P47_S5	These adjustments related primarily to raw materials of retired patterns and certain merchandise from the baby gift category, which is being discontinued by the Company, as we have the ability to move retired finished goods through a number of channels, including the annual outlet sale, our website and outlet stores, and through liquidators as needed.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	Income Taxes Our effective tax rate is based on our pre-tax income, statutory tax rates, tax laws and regulations, and tax planning opportunities available in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our annual tax expense and in evaluating our tax positions.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P48_S2	We establish reserves to remove some or all of the tax benefit of any of our tax positions at the time we determine that the positions become uncertain based upon one of the following: (1) the tax position is not more likely than not to be sustained; (2) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but for a lesser amount; or (3) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but not in the financial period in which the tax position was originally taken.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	Taxing authorities periodically audit our income tax returns.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	We believe that our tax filing positions are reasonable and legally supportable.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P49_S2	Taxing authorities, however, may take a contrary position.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P49_S3	Our results of operations and effective tax rate in a given period could be impacted if, upon final resolution with taxing authorities, we prevail in positions for which we have established reserves, or are required to pay amounts in excess of established reserves.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	Valuation of Long-lived Assets Property, plant, and equipment assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	In evaluating an asset for recoverability, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset at the store level, the lowest identifiable level of cash flow, if applicable.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	If the sum of the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the asset is less than the carrying value, we recognize a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, usually determined by an estimated discounted cash flow analysis of the asset.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	Factors used in the valuation of long-lived assets include, but are not limited to, our plans for future operations, brand initiatives, recent operating results, and projected future cash flows.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	With respect to our stores, we analyze store economics, location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies in our selection process.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	Impairment charges are classified in SG A expenses and were $1.2 million and $0.2 million for the periods ended February 1, 2014 and February 2, 2013, respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	The discounted cash flow models used to estimate the applicable fair values involve numerous estimates and assumptions that are highly subjective.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	Changes to these estimates and assumptions could materially impact the fair value estimates.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S2	The estimates and assumptions critical to the overall fair value estimates include: (1) estimated future cash flow generated at the store level; and (2) discount rates used to derive the present value factors used in determining the fair values.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S3	These and other estimates and assumptions are impacted by economic conditions and our expectations and may change in the future based on period-specific facts and circumstances.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S4	If economic conditions were to deteriorate, future impairment charges may be required.
1495320_14_ITEM7_P55_S5	Transactions with Related Parties See Item 13, Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, and Director Independence, of this report for information regarding transactions with related parties.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are subject to interest rate risk in connection with borrowings under our amended and restated credit agreement, which bear interest at variable rates.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The amended and restated credit agreement allows for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million, bearing interest at a variable rate, based on either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05%) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05%).
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Assuming the amended and restated credit agreement is fully drawn, each quarter point increase or decrease in the interest rate would change our annual interest expense by approximately $0.3 million.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Impact of Inflation Our results of operations and financial condition are presented based on historical cost.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Although it is difficult to accurately measure the impact of inflation due to the imprecise nature of the estimates required, we believe the effects of inflation, if any, on our results of operations and financial condition have been immaterial.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Foreign Exchange Rate Risk We source a majority of our materials from various suppliers in China and South Korea.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Substantially all purchases and sales involving foreign persons are denominated in U.S. dollars, and therefore we do not hedge using any derivative instruments.
1495320_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Historically, we have not been impacted materially by changes in exchange rates.

1495320_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	Description of the Company Vera Bradley is a leading designer, producer, marketer, and retailer of stylish, highly functional accessories for women.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	The Company s products include a wide offering of handbags, accessories, and travel and leisure items.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P11_S2	The Company generates net revenues by selling products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P11_S3	The Direct segment consists of sales of Vera Bradley products through our 84 full-price stores, our 15 outlet stores in the United States, 13 department store locations in Japan, our websites, verabradley.com and verabradley.co.jp, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P11_S4	The Indirect business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 3,100 specialty retailers, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as select department stores and third-party e-commerce sites.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	Except where context requires or where otherwise indicated, the terms Vera Bradley and Company refer to Vera Bradley, Inc. and its subsidiaries, including Vera Bradley Designs, Inc.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P13_S1	The Company has eliminated intercompany balances and transactions in consolidation.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P13_S2	The Company utilizes a 52 - 53 week fiscal year ending on the Saturday closest to January 31.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P13_S3	As such, fiscal 2014 ended on February 1, 2014 and reflected a 52 -week period; fiscal 2013 and 2012 ended on February 2, 2013 , and January 28, 2012 , and reflected 53 -week and 52 -week periods, respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P13_S4	The inclusion of the 53 rd week in fiscal 2013 resulted in incremental revenues of approximately $4.9 million and approximately $0.02 per diluted share.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of the Company s assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	Significant areas requiring the use of management estimates include the valuation of inventories, accounts receivable valuation allowances, sales return allowances, and the useful lives of assets for depreciation or amortization.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P14_S2	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P14_S3	The Company revises its estimates and assumptions as new information becomes available.

1495320_14_ITEM8_P15_S2	The Company monitors the credit standing of this financial institution on a regular basis.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P16_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P16_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P16_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	Property, Plant, and Equipment Property, plant, and equipment are carried at cost and depreciated or amortized over the following estimated useful lives using the straight-line method:
1495320_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the life of the asset or the lease term.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	Lease terms typically range from five to ten years.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	When a decision is made to abandon property, plant, and equipment prior to the end of the previously estimated useful life, depreciation or amortization estimates are revised to reflect the use of the asset over the shortened estimated useful life.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	At the time of disposal, the cost of assets sold or retired and the related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts and any resulting loss is included in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	Property, plant, and equipment are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be recoverable.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P20_S1	The reviews are conducted at the lowest identifiable level of cash flows.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	If the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the property, plant, and equipment are less than the carrying value, the Company recognizes a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, as further defined below in Fair Value of Financial Instruments.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Routine maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs incurred in connection with acquiring, modifying, and installing internal-use software.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P23_S1	Capitalized costs are included in property, plant, and equipment and are amortized over three to five years .
1495320_14_ITEM8_P23_S2	Software costs that do not meet capitalization criteria are expensed as incurred.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	Revenue Recognition and Accounts Receivable Revenue from the sale of the Company s products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an adjustment for shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	The adjustment of these shipments is based on actual delivery dates to the customer.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	Included in net revenues are product sales to Direct and Indirect customers, including amounts billed to customers for shipping fees.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	Costs related to shipping of product are classified in cost of sales in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P25_S2	Net revenues exclude sales taxes collected from customers and remitted to governmental authorities.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	Historical experience provides the Company the ability to estimate reasonably the amount of product sales that customers will return.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	Product returns are often resalable through the Company s annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	The Company accounts for anticipated returns by reducing net revenues, cost of sales, and accounts receivable and increasing inventories, essentially reversing the effects of the original sales transactions.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P26_S3	Additionally, the Company reserves for other potential product credits granted to Indirect retailers.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P26_S4	The returns and credits reserve and the related activity for each fiscal year presented were as follows (in thousands):
1495320_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	The Company establishes an allowance for doubtful accounts based on historical experience and customer-specific identification and believes that collections of receivables, net of the allowance for doubtful accounts, are reasonably assured.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	The allowance for doubtful accounts was approximately $0.3 million and $0.7 million at February 1, 2014 , and February 2, 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company sells gift cards with no expiration dates to customers and does not charge administrative fees on unused gift cards.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	Gift cards issued by the Company are recorded as a liability until they are redeemed, at which point revenue is recognized.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P28_S2	The Company currently does not recognize breakage on its gift cards.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Cost of Sales Cost of sales includes material and labor costs, freight, inventory shrinkage, operating lease costs, duty, and other operating expenses, including depreciation of the Company s distribution center and equipment.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	Costs and related expenses to manufacture and distribute the products are recorded as cost of sales when the related revenues are recognized.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	The Company has leases that contain rent holidays and predetermined, fixed escalations of minimum rentals.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	For each of these leases, the Company recognizes the related rent expense on a straight-line basis commencing on the date of initial possession of the leased property.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P30_S2	The Company records the difference between the recognized rent expense and the amount payable under the lease as a step-up rent liability.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P30_S3	As of February 1, 2014 and February 2, 2013 , step-up rent liability was $7.0 million and $5.5 million , respectively and is included within other accrued liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	The Company receives tenant-improvement allowances from some of the landlords of its leased properties.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	These allowances generally are in the form of cash received by the Company from its landlords as part of the negotiated lease terms.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P31_S2	The Company records each tenant-improvement allowance as a deferred credit and amortizes the allowance on a straight-line basis as a reduction to rent expense over the term of the lease, commencing on the possession date.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P31_S3	As of February 1, 2014 and February 2, 2013 , the deferred lease credit liability was $10.3 million and $8.5 million , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P31_S4	Of this, $1.4 million and $1.1 million is included within other accrued liabilities and $8.9 million and $7.4 million is included within other long term liabilities as of February 1, 2014 and February 2, 2013 , respectively.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	The Company charges costs associated with the opening of new stores to selling, general, and administrative expenses as incurred.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	Selling, general, and administrative expenses also include store operating costs, store employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	Stock-Based Compensation The Company accounts for stock-based compensation using the fair-value recognition provisions of ASC 718, Stock Compensation.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	Under these provisions, for its awards of restricted stock and restricted-stock units, the Company recognizes stock-based compensation expense in an amount equal to the fair market value of the underlying stock on the grant date of the respective award.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P33_S2	The Company recognizes this expense, net of estimated forfeitures, on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period.

1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	The amended and restated credit agreement provides for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million and matures on October 3, 2015 .
1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S2	All borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement are collateralized by substantially all of the Company s assets.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S3	The credit agreement is also guaranteed by the Company.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S4	The credit agreement requires the Company to comply with various financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.20 to 1.00 and a leverage ratio of not more than 3.50 to 1.00 .
1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S5	The agreement also contains various other covenants, including restrictions on the incurrence of certain indebtedness, liens, investments, acquisitions, and asset sales.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P45_S6	The Company was in compliance with these covenants as of February 1, 2014 .
1495320_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	Borrowings under the amended and restated credit agreement bear interest at either LIBOR plus the applicable margin (ranging from 1.05% to 2.05% ) or the alternate base rate (as defined in the agreement) plus the applicable margin (ranging from 0.05% to 1.05% ).
1495320_14_ITEM8_P46_S1	The applicable margin is tied to the Company s leverage ratio.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P46_S2	In addition, the Company is required to pay a quarterly facility fee (as defined in the agreement) ranging from 0.20% to 0.45% of the revolving credit commitment.
1495320_14_ITEM8_P46_S3	As of February 1, 2014 , the Company had borrowing availability of $125.0 million .

1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer of women s handbags, accessories, and luggage and travel items.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S1	Founded in 1982 by friends Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia R. Miller, the brand s iconic designs and versatile styles offer women of all ages a colorful way to accessorize every look.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S2	Vera Bradley offers a unique, multi-channel sales model, as well as a focus on service and a high level of customer engagement.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S3	The Company sells its products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S4	The Direct business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products through the Company s full-line and factory outlet stores in the United States, verabradley.com, direct-to-consumer eBay sales, and the Company's annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P0_S5	As of January 31, 2015 , the Company operated 96 full-line stores and 29 factory outlet stores.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Indirect business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 2,700 specialty retail locations, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, the Company's wholesale business in Japan, and third party inventory liquidation.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P1_S1	For financial information about our reportable segments, refer to Note 17 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Part II, Item 8.

1495320_15_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our History Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller founded the Company in 1982 in Fort Wayne, Indiana, after recognizing a lack of stylish travel accessories in the market.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P2_S1	Within weeks, the friends created Vera Bradley, named after Ms. Bradley Baekgaard s mother, and began manufacturing and marketing their distinctive products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P2_S2	The founders, together with past and present members of the executive management team, have been instrumental in our growth and success.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P2_S3	The following timeline sets forth a summary of significant milestones in Vera Bradley s history:
1495320_15_ITEM1_P3_S0	Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller launched Vera Bradley by introducing three products: the handbag, the sports bag, and the duffel bag.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P4_S0	Ernst Young honored our Co-Founders with an Entrepreneur of the Year award.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P5_S0	To accommodate the increasing number of attendees, we relocated our annual outlet sale from a tent in our parking lot to its present location at the Allen County War Memorial Coliseum Exposition Center in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P6_S0	We founded our primary philanthropy, the Vera Bradley Foundation for Breast Cancer.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P7_S0	Our products were being sold in all 50 states through Indirect retailers.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P8_S0	We launched the Vera Bradley Visual Merchandising Program, providing our retail partners a framework for presenting the brand and merchandising our products in a consistent manner.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P9_S0	We launched our e-commerce business through our website, verabradley.com.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P10_S0	We opened a state-of-the-art distribution facility in Roanoke, Indiana.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P10_S1	In September, we also opened our first full-line store at the Natick Collection, in greater Boston.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P11_S0	We opened our first outlet store at Chicago Premium Outlets in Aurora, Illinois.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P12_S0	We completed our initial public offering.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P13_S0	We opened the Vera Bradley Design Center in Roanoke, Indiana, and launched our products in 65 Dillard s locations.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P14_S0	We completed the 200,000 square-foot expansion of the distribution facility in Roanoke, Indiana; increased our presence to all Dillard s locations; and launched a relationship with Von Maur, and are carried in all of their locations.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P15_S0	We migrated verabradley.com to a more responsive design, providing an enhanced shopping experience and optimal product viewing regardless of the device being used to shop.

1495320_15_ITEM1_P16_S2	Ms. Miller retired in October 2012 as our National Spokesperson, but continues to serve on the Board of Directors.

1495320_15_ITEM1_P39_S5	In 2006, we began selling our products through the verabradley.com website.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P39_S6	The objective of verabradley.com is to provide both a mechanism for marketing directly to consumers and a storefront where consumers can find the entire Vera Bradley collection.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P39_S7	In fiscal 2013, we invested in upgrades to our website allowing for a more user friendly homepage, enabling us to ship internationally to 15 countries, and enhancing the checkout experience.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P39_S8	In fiscal 2015, we made additional enhancements to our website, including adding product recommendations, enhancing product descriptions, adding silhouettes for product scale, generating cart and site abandonment emails, and gathering and analyzing customer feedback.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P39_S9	We had over 73 million visits to verabradley.com during fiscal 2015 .
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S0	Our factory outlet stores are a vehicle for selling retired merchandise at discounted prices, as well as factory exclusive styles, while maintaining brand integrity.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S1	At the end of fiscal 2015, approximately 25% of the merchandise found in our factory outlet stores was factory exclusive styles.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S2	We expect factory exclusive merchandise to grow to 70% of all factory outlet merchandise in the coming years.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S3	We believe our factory outlet stores are an integral part of our distribution strategy, as this format provides an additional channel of distribution for our products and enables us to better target value-oriented customers.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S4	Our factory outlet stores average approximately 3,200 square feet per store.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S5	As of January 31, 2015 , we operated 29 factory outlet stores.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S6	Our annual outlet sale is held in the Allen County War Memorial Coliseum Exposition Center in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S7	The annual outlet sale is an important tradition for Vera Bradley, has many loyal followers, and is an opportunity for us to sell our retired merchandise at discounted prices in a brand-right fashion.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P40_S8	We attracted approximately 59,000 attendees to our 2014 annual outlet sale.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our store location decisions are made based upon our comprehensive retail strategy that includes actual and planned penetration in both Indirect and Direct segments, as well as existing e-commerce demand.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P41_S1	At this time, we do not believe any market has been fully penetrated.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P41_S2	We believe that expansion of our store base complements our Indirect segment by increasing brand awareness and reinforcing our brand image.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S0	In addition to analyzing store economics, we pay particular attention to the location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S1	Along with seeking co-tenants that we believe share our target customer, we seek a balanced mix of moderate and high-end retailers to encourage high levels of traffic.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S2	Our target full-line store size is approximately 1,800 square feet, but we are able to work with spaces as small as 1,000 square feet or, depending on our market strategy and relevant economic factors, spaces as large as 2,800 square feet.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S3	Our target factory outlet store size is approximately 3,000 square feet.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S4	The focus of our store operations is providing consumers with a comfortable and memorable shopping experience.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S5	We strive to make the experience interactive through special store events, such as showcasing newly launched products or celebrating our namesake s birthday.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S6	Our customer service philosophy emphasizes friendly service, merchandise knowledge, and passion for the brand.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P42_S7	Consequently, an essential requirement for the success of our stores is our ability to attract, train, and retain talented, highly motivated district managers, store managers, and sales associates.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S0	Store Economics We believe that our retail concept and distinctive retail experience contribute to the success of our stores, most of which generate solid productivity and returns.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S1	We expect our full-line stores to average approximately 1,800 square feet per store, and we expect to invest approximately $0.4 million per new store, consisting of inventory costs, pre-opening costs, and build-out costs, less tenant-improvement allowances.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S2	New full-line stores generate, on average, approximately $1.0 million in net revenues during the first twelve months, and the payback on our investment is expected to occur in less than 22 months.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S3	We expect our factory outlet stores to average approximately 3,000 square feet per store, and we expect to invest approximately $0.4 million per new store, consisting of inventory costs, pre-opening costs, and build-out costs, less tenant-improvement allowances.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S4	New factory outlet stores generate, on average, approximately $2.6 million in net revenues during the first twelve months, and the payback on our investment is expected to occur in less than 12 months.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S5	As of January 31, 2015 , we sold our products in approximately 2,700 specialty retail locations, the majority of which we have had long-standing relationships with, as well as department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, our wholesale business in Japan and third-party inventory liquidation.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S6	The top 30% of our specialty retailers account for approximately 70% of revenue from our specialty retailers.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S7	No single account represented more than 10% of total Indirect net revenues in fiscal 2015 , with the top ten accounts representing in the aggregate approximately 30% of total Indirect net revenues.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S8	The majority of our Indirect retailers have been customers for over five years.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S9	In fiscal 2012, we launched our products in the department store channel.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S10	We believe that having an in-house sales force results in more consistent brand presentation and messaging, enhanced support for our Indirect retailers, and a more predictable, scalable, and cost-efficient business model.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S11	As of January 31, 2015 , our sales team consisted of approximately 65 in-house, full-time sales consultants.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S12	The compensation structure for our sales consultants consists of a combination of fixed pay and sales-based incentives.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S13	In addition to acquiring new and growing existing accounts, our sales consultants serve as a support center for our Indirect retailers by assisting and educating them in areas such as merchandising and visual presentation, marketing of the brand, product selection, and inventory management.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P43_S14	Our visual merchandising program provides our sales consultants with a framework to guide our Indirect retailers regarding optimal product placement and display that is intended to reinforce the message that our brand is distinct from those of our competitors.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S0	Manufacturing and Supply Chain Model Our broad-based, multi-country manufacturing and supply chain model is designed to achieve efficient, timely, and accurate order fulfillment while maintaining appropriate levels of inventory.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S1	Our sourcing strategy is part of the larger cross-functional product development process.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S2	The overall objective for our sourcing team is to build and sustain collaborative partnerships throughout our supply chain, with a focus on identifying appropriate countries and partners to manufacture our products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S3	The sourcing team leverages its expertise in negotiation, relationship management, and change management to maintain a strong global supply chain.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S4	We strive to maintain the appropriate balance of inventory to enable us to provide a high level of service to our customers, including prompt and accurate delivery of our products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S5	We have an active sales and operations planning process that helps us balance the supply and demand issues that we encounter in our business, optimize our inventory levels, and anticipate inventory needs.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P44_S6	We have also integrated our planning, forecasting, and segmentation processes under one function called Merchandise Planning and Allocation.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S0	The majority of our products are cotton-based.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S1	Our other products are made primarily from specialty fabrics, including nylon, microfiber, leather, and faux leather.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S2	We source our materials from various suppliers in Asia, with the majority coming from China and South Korea.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S3	Our global sourcing team works with select suppliers enabling us to optimize the mix of cost, lead time, quality, and reliability within our global supply network.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S4	All of our suppliers must comply with our quality standards, and we use only a limited number of pre-approved suppliers who have demonstrated a commitment to delivering the highest quality products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P45_S5	In December 2008, we opened an office in Dongguan, China, which enables us to increase our control over the manufacturing and supply chain process and monitor compliance with our quality standards.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P46_S0	Virtually all of our finished goods products are manufactured externally overseas.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P46_S1	These products are made by a variety of global manufacturers located primarily in China.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P46_S2	We are not dependent upon any single manufacturer for our products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P46_S3	When determining the size of orders placed with our manufacturers, we take into account forward-looking demand, lead times for specific products, current inventory levels, and minimum order quantity requirements.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P47_S0	Overseas production has resulted in substantial cost savings and a reduction of capital investment.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P47_S1	With the oversight of our office in China and our independent contractors, we believe these financial benefits have been realized without sacrificing the level of quality inherent in our products or service to our customers.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P47_S2	On March 10, 2015, we announced that we plan to close our manufacturing facility located in New Haven, Indiana (metropolitan Fort Wayne) beginning early in fiscal 2016, unless business conditions necessitate earlier action.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P47_S3	Refer to Note 16 of the Consolidated Financial Statements, herein, for additional information.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S0	In 2007, we consolidated our warehousing and shipping functions into one, 217,320 square-foot distribution center, located in Roanoke, Indiana.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S1	In fiscal 2013, we completed a 200,000 square-foot expansion of the distribution facility.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S2	This automated, computerized facility allows Vera Bradley employees to receive information directly from the order-collection center and quickly identify the products and quantities necessary for a particular order.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S3	The recent expansion resulted in capacity gains in the areas of inbound receiving, inventory storage, order fulfillment, value-add processing and shipping.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S4	The facility s advanced technology enables us to more accurately process and pack orders, as well as track shipments and inventory.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S5	We believe that our systems for the processing and shipment of orders from our distribution center have enabled us to improve our overall customer service through enhanced order accuracy and reduced turnaround time.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S6	Our products are shipped primarily via FedEx and common carriers to our stores, our Indirect retailers and department stores, and directly to our customers who purchase through our website.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S7	We believe we are positioned well to support the order fulfillment requirements of our business, including business generated through our website.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S8	We believe that high levels of automation and technology are essential to maintain our competitive position.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S9	We maintain computer hardware, systems applications, and networks to enhance and accelerate the design process, to support the sale and distribution of our products to our customers, and to improve the integration and efficiency of our operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S10	Our management information systems are designed to provide, among other things, comprehensive order processing, production, accounting, and management information for the product development, retail, sales, marketing, manufacturing, distribution, finance, and human resources functions of our business.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P48_S11	We use several systems, including MICROS-Retail, SAP, JDA, and SCALE for our information technology requirements.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S0	Competition We face strong competition in each of the product lines and markets in which we compete.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S1	We believe that all of our products are in similar competitive positions with respect to the number of competitors they face and the level of competition within each product line.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S2	Due to the number of different products we offer, it is not practicable for us to quantify the number of competitors we face.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S3	Our products compete with other branded products within their product categories and with private label products sold by retailers.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S4	In our Indirect business, we compete with numerous manufacturers, importers, and distributors of handbags, accessories, and other products for the limited space available for the display of such products to the consumer.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P49_S5	Moreover, the general availability of contract manufacturing allows new entrants access to the markets in which we compete, which may increase the number of competitors and adversely affect our competitive position and our business.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S0	In our Direct business, we compete against other independent retailers, department stores, catalog retailers, gift retailers, and Internet businesses that engage in the retail sale of similar products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S1	The market for handbags, in particular, is highly competitive.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S2	Our competitors include not only established companies that are expanding their production and marketing of handbags, but also frequent new entrants to the market.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S3	We directly compete with wholesalers and direct sellers of branded handbags and accessories, such as Coach, Nine West, Liz Claiborne, Dooney Bourke, Kate Spade, Michael Kors, Fossil, Brahmin, and Tory Burch.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S4	In varying degrees, depending on the product category involved, we compete on the basis of design (aesthetic appeal), quality (construction), function, price point, distribution, and brand positioning.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S5	We believe that our primary competitive advantages are consumer recognition of our brand, customer loyalty, product development expertise, and our widespread presence through our multi-channel distribution model.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P50_S6	Some of our competitors have achieved significant recognition for their brand names or have substantially greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other resources than we do.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P51_S0	competitors and increased competition from existing competitors as we expand into new markets and increase our presence in existing markets.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S0	Copyrights and Trademarks The development of new patterns includes the design of an overall print, and may also include a complementary fabric backing, and coordinating trim materials.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S1	Once developed, we generally copyright each pattern, including any fabric backing and coordinating trim.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S2	We currently have approximately 700 copyrights.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S3	We also own all of the material trademark rights used in connection with the production, marketing, and distribution of all of our products, both in the United States and in the other countries in which our products are principally sold.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S4	We aggressively police our trademarks and copyrights and pursue infringers and counterfeiters both domestically and internationally.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S5	Our trademarks will remain in existence for as long as we continue to use and renew them on their expiration dates.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S6	Employees As of January 31, 2015 , we had approximately 2,800 employees.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S7	Of the total, 1,850 were engaged in retail selling positions, 565 were engaged in manufacturing and distribution functions, 35 were engaged in product design, and 350 were engaged in corporate support and administrative functions.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S8	None of our employees are represented by a union.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S9	We believe that our relations with our employees are good, and we have never encountered a significant work stoppage.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S10	Many of our imported products are subject to existing or potential duties, tariffs, or quotas that may limit the quantity of products that we may import into the United States and other countries or impact the cost of such products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S11	To date, we have not been restricted by quotas in the operation of our business, and customs duties have not comprised a material portion of the total cost of a majority of our products.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S12	In addition, we are subject to foreign governmental regulation and trade restrictions, including U.S. retaliation against prohibited foreign practices, with respect to our product sourcing and international sales operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S13	We are subject to federal, state, local, and foreign laws and regulations governing environmental matters, including the handling, transportation, and disposal of our products and our non-hazardous and hazardous substances and wastes, as well as emissions and discharges into the environment, including discharges to air, surface water, and groundwater.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P52_S14	Failure to comply with such laws and regulations could result in costs for corrective action, penalties, or the imposition of other liabilities.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P53_S0	Compliance with environmental laws and regulations has not had a material effect upon our earnings or financial position.
1495320_15_ITEM1_P53_S1	If we violate any laws or regulations, however, it could have a material adverse effect on our business or financial performance.

1495320_15_ITEM1_P62_S0	Our Annual Report on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, Current Reports on Form 8-K, and all amendments to these reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are available free of charge on our website, www.verabradley.com, as soon as reasonably practicable after they are filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ).

1495320_15_ITEM1A_P0_S0	If we are unable to successfully implement our long-term strategic plan and growth strategies, our future operating results could suffer.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S0	In fiscal 2015, we began to implement a long-term strategic plan focused on product, distribution and marketing strategies intended to profitably grow our business.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The success of our long-term strategic plan and these growth strategies, alone or collectively, will depend on various factors, including the appeal of our product designs, retail presentation to consumers, effectiveness of our marketing initiatives, competitive conditions, and economic conditions.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S2	There is no assurance that we will be able to successfully implement our strategic plan.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S3	If we are unsuccessful in implementing some or all of our strategies or initiatives, our future operating results could be adversely impacted.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S4	If our multi-channel distribution model is not successful, our business and results of operations may suffer.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S5	We currently sell into two segments: Direct to consumers through our full-line and factory outlet stores in the United States, verabradley.com, direct-to-consumer eBay sales, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana; and through our Indirect wholesale business which consists of sales to approximately 2,700 specialty retail locations, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, the Company's wholesale business in Japan, and third party inventory liquidation.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S6	These channels are sometimes in direct competition and sales through these channels may not be incremental to total sales.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S7	For example, we are continuing to invest in our specialty retailers to support them in growing along with Vera Bradley.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S8	This channel will continue to evolve over time as we balance the channel dynamics between the specialty retailers, department stores, our Direct stores, and e-commerce.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P1_S9	Changes in general economic conditions, and their impact on consumer confidence and consumer spending, could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our performance is subject to general economic conditions and their impact on levels of consumer confidence and consumer spending.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Consumer confidence and consumer spending may be influenced by fluctuating interest rates and credit availability, changing fuel and other energy costs, fluctuating commodity prices, levels of unemployment and consumer debt levels, changes in net worth based on market conditions, general uncertainty regarding the overall future economic environment, and weather and weather-related phenomena.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Consumer purchases of discretionary items, including our merchandise, generally decline during periods when disposable income is adversely affected or there is economic uncertainty, and this could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S3	In the event that the U.S. economy does not sustain its current recovery, renewed decline in consumer-spending levels and other conditions, including inflation, we could experience lower than expected net revenues, which could force us to delay or slow the implementation of our growth strategies and adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Our inability to predict and respond in a timely manner to changes in consumer demand could adversely affect our net revenues and results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Our success depends on our ability to gauge the fashion tastes of our customers and to provide merchandise that satisfies consumer demand in a timely manner.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S6	Our products must appeal to a broad range of consumers whose preferences cannot be predicted with certainty and are subject to rapid change.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S7	We cannot assure you that we will be able to continue to develop appealing patterns and styles or meet changing consumer demands in the future.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S8	If we misjudge the market for our products, we may be faced with significant excess inventories for some products and missed opportunities for other products.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S9	In addition, changes to our product assortment and to our available fabrications, as well as the availability and breadth of pattern assortment may not gain consumer acceptance.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P2_S10	Merchandise misjudgments could adversely impact our net revenues and results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may not be able to successfully open new stores and/or operate new and current stores as planned, which could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Our future growth will depend on our ability to successfully open and operate new and current stores.

1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S2	If we are not able to achieve the projected key financial metrics for any reason, including because any of the strategic initiatives being implemented do not result in significant improvements in our current financial performance trend, this would indicate that the value of our long-lived assets was not recoverable and we would incur additional impairment of assets in the future.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S3	In the event we record additional impairment charges, this could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S4	Our Indirect business could suffer as a result of bankruptcies or operational or financial difficulties of our Indirect retailers.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S5	We do not enter into long-term agreements with any of our Indirect retailers.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S6	Instead, we enter into a number of purchase order commitments with our customers for each of our lines every season.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S7	A decision by a significant number of Indirect retailers, whether motivated by competitive conditions, operational or financial difficulties, reduced access to capital, or otherwise, to decrease or eliminate the amount of merchandise purchased from us or to change their manner of doing business with us could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S8	Although we recommend retail sale prices for our products to our Indirect retailers, we do not provide dealer allowances or other economic incentives to support those prices.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P32_S9	Possible promotional pricing or discounting by Indirect retailers in response to softening retail demand could have a negative effect on our brand image and prestige, which might be difficult to counteract as the economy improves.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We sell our Indirect merchandise primarily to specialty retail stores across the United States and extend trade credit based on an evaluation of each Indirect retailer s financial condition, usually without requiring collateral.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Perceived financial difficulties of a customer could cause us to curtail or eliminate business with that customer.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Pending the resolution of a relationship with a financially troubled Indirect retailer, we might assume credit risk that we would otherwise avoid relating to our receivables from that customer.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S2	Inability to collect on accounts receivable from our Indirect retailers would adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S3	There are claims made against us from time to time that can result in litigation or regulatory proceedings, which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability or damage to our brand image.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S4	As a growing company with expanding operations, we increasingly face the risk of litigation and other claims against us.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S5	Litigation and other claims may arise in the ordinary course of our business and include employee claims, custom and duty claims, commercial disputes, intellectual property issues, product-oriented allegations, and slip and fall claims.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S6	Often these cases raise complex factual and legal issues, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S7	Litigation and other claims against us could result in unexpected expenses and liability, as well as materially adversely affect our operations and our reputation.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P34_S8	Changes in the health care regulatory environment could cause us to incur additional expense and our failure to comply with related legal requirements could have a material adverse effect on our business.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P35_S0	In 2010, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 were signed into law in the U.S.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P35_S1	This legislation expands health care coverage to many uninsured individuals and expands coverage for those already insured.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P35_S2	We do not expect any material short-term impact on our financial results as a result of the legislation; however, as additional requirements from the legislation continue to go into effect, we expect to incur an increase in our expenses.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P35_S3	If this legislation and future changes in health care legislation significantly increase our expenses, our financial condition and results of operations could be adversely affected.

1495320_15_ITEM1A_P36_S0	These and other factors may result in a lower market price of our common stock, regardless of our actual operating performance.

1495320_15_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We could become engaged in a consent solicitation, or proxy contest, or experience other stockholder activism, in the future.

1495320_15_ITEM1A_P39_S2	In addition, if faced with a consent solicitation or proxy contest, we may not be able to respond successfully to the contest or dispute, which would be disruptive to our business.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P39_S3	Even if we are successful, if individuals are elected to our Board with a differing agenda, our ability to effectively and timely implement our strategic plan and create additional value for our stockholders may be adversely affected.
1495320_15_ITEM1A_P39_S4	A limited number of shareholders control a large percentage of the voting power of our common stock, and therefore investors may have limited ability to determine the outcome of shareholder votes.
