1495320_16_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Further, possible changes in federal, state, local, and non-U.S. tax laws bearing upon our revenues, income, property, or other aspects of our operations or business would, if enacted, affect our results of operations in ways and to a degree that we cannot currently predict.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We have recorded asset impairment charges in the past and we may record material asset impairment charges in the future.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Quarterly, we assess whether events or changes in circumstances have occurred that indicate the carrying value of long-lived assets may not be recoverable.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S1	If we determine that the carrying value of long-lived assets is not recoverable, we will be required to record impairment charges relating to those assets.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S2	For example, our assessments during fiscal 2016 indicated that operating losses or insufficient operating income existed at certain retail stores, with a projection that the operating losses or insufficient operating income for those locations would continue.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S3	As such, we recorded non-cash charges of $2.8 million during fiscal 2016 within asset impairment in the consolidated statements of operations to write down the carrying values of these stores' long-lived assets to their estimated fair values.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S4	Our quarterly evaluation of store assets includes consideration of current and historical performance and projections of future profitability.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S5	The profitability projections rely upon estimates made by us, including store-level sales, gross margins, and direct expenses, and, by their nature, include judgments about how current strategic initiatives will impact future performance.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S6	If we are not able to achieve the projected key financial metrics for any reason, including because any of the strategic initiatives being implemented do not result in significant improvements in our current financial performance trend, this would indicate that the value of our long-lived assets was not recoverable and we would incur additional impairment of assets in the future.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P32_S7	In the event we record additional impairment charges, this could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our Indirect business could suffer as a result of decisions by our Indirect retailers to decrease or eliminate the amount of merchandise purchased from us.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We do not enter into long-term agreements with any of our Indirect retailers.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S2	Instead, we enter into a number of purchase order commitments with our customers for each of our lines every season.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S3	A decision by a significant number of Indirect retailers, whether motivated by competitive conditions, operational or financial difficulties, reduced access to capital, or otherwise, to decrease or eliminate the amount of merchandise purchased from us or to change their manner of doing business with us could adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S4	Although we recommend retail sale prices for our products to our Indirect retailers, we do not provide dealer allowances or other economic incentives to support those prices.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S5	Possible promotional pricing or discounting by Indirect retailers in response to softening retail demand could have a negative effect on our brand image and prestige, which might be difficult to counteract as the economy improves.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S6	Bankruptcies or other operational or financial difficulties of our Indirect retailers could adversely impact our business.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S7	We sell our Indirect merchandise primarily to specialty retail and department stores across the United States and extend trade credit based on an evaluation of each Indirect retailer s financial condition, usually without requiring collateral.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S8	Perceived or actual financial difficulties of a customer could cause us to curtail or eliminate business with that customer or could decrease demand for our products by that customer.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S9	Pending the resolution of a relationship with a financially troubled Indirect retailer, we might assume credit risk that we would otherwise avoid relating to our receivables from that customer.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S10	Inability to collect on accounts receivable from our Indirect retailers would adversely impact our results of operations.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S11	There are claims made against us from time to time that can result in litigation or regulatory proceedings, which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability or damage to our brand image.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S12	As a growing company with expanding operations, we increasingly face the risk of litigation and other claims against us.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S13	Litigation and other claims may arise in the ordinary course of our business and include employee claims, custom and duty claims, commercial disputes, intellectual property issues, product-oriented allegations, and slip and fall claims.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S14	Often these cases raise complex factual and legal issues, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S15	Litigation and other claims against us could result in unexpected expenses and liability, as well as materially adversely affect our operations and our reputation.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S16	We may suffer negative publicity and our business may be harmed if we need to recall any products we sell.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S17	We have in the past needed to, and may in the future need to, recall products that we determine may present safety issues.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S18	If products we sell have safety problems of which we are not aware, or if we or the Consumer Product Safety Commission recall a product sold in our stores, we may suffer negative publicity and, potentially, product liability lawsuits, which could have a material adverse impact on our reputation, financial condition and results of operations or cash flows.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S19	Risks Related to the Securities Markets and Ownership of Our Common Stock Our stock price may be volatile or may decline regardless of our operating performance, and you may not be able to resell shares at or above the price at which you purchase them.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P33_S20	The market price of our common stock may fluctuate significantly in response to a number of factors, most of which we cannot control, including:
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P34_S0	These and other factors may result in a lower market price of our common stock, regardless of our actual operating performance.

1495320_16_ITEM1A_P34_S2	In the past, stockholders have instituted securities class action litigation following periods of market volatility.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P34_S3	If we were involved in securities litigation, we could incur substantial costs and our resources and the attention of management could be diverted from our business.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P34_S4	Our business could be negatively affected as a result of the actions of activist stockholders.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Over the last few years, proxy contests and other forms of stockholder activism have been directed against numerous public companies in retail businesses.
1495320_16_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We could become engaged in a consent solicitation, or proxy contest, or experience other stockholder activism, in the future.

1495320_16_ITEM1A_P37_S3	If individuals are elected to our Board with a differing agenda, our ability to effectively and timely implement our strategic plan and create additional value for our stockholders may be adversely affected.

1495320_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	Executive summary Fiscal 2016 was the second year of our multi-year turnaround, and we made significant progress against key elements of our long-term strategic plan, laid out in March 2014, focusing on the key planks of product, distribution, and marketing.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	We made progress on our product strategies, including:
1495320_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	Substantially enhancing our gross profit percentage through sourcing efficiencies, higher penetration of our Made for Outlet ( MFO ) product, and meaningfully reducing our promotional activity.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	We made progress on our distribution strategies, including:
1495320_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Nearly doubling our department store presence at Macy s, adding distribution at select Belk and Bon-Ton stores, and beginning our Amazon partnership.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	We began to modernize our marketing and increase brand and product awareness through:
1495320_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	Introducing our Campus Ambassador program on several college campuses.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Other charges affecting comparability were $3.1 million ( $2.1 million after the associated tax benefit) in fiscal 2016 .
1495320_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Capital expenditures for fiscal 2016 totaled $26.3 millio n, which were funded from cash generated from operations of $43.3 million .
1495320_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	In June 2014, we entered into a five-year agreement with Mitsubishi Corporation Fashion Company and Look Inc. for the importation and distribution of Vera Bradley products in Japan.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	As a result of moving to this wholesale business model, we exited our direct business in Japan during the third quarter of fiscal 2015 and have accounted for it as a discontinued operation.

1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	Restructuring and Other Charges Affecting Comparability of the Year-to-Date Periods ended January 30, 2016, and January 31, 2015 In the first quarter of fiscal 2016, the Company closed its manufacturing facility located in New Haven, Indiana.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	The Company incurred restructuring and other charges during the first quarter of fiscal 2016 of approximately $3.4 million ($2.1 million after the associated tax benefit), related to the facility closing, as compared to $3.0 million ($1.9 million after the associated tax benefit), primarily related to raw materials inventory write-downs, in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S3	The fiscal 2016 charges include severance and benefit costs of approximately $1.7 million, lease termination costs of approximately $0.7 million, inventory-related charges of approximately $0.6 million, and other associated net costs, which include accelerated depreciation related to fixed assets, of approximately $0.4 million.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S4	These charges are reflected in cost of sales in the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S5	Management expects that the facility closure will reduce operating costs by approximately $12.0 million annually beginning in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P10_S6	All production from the facility will be absorbed by the Company s third party manufacturing suppliers.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	Additional charges affecting comparability of the financial results for the fifty-two weeks ended January 30, 2016 and January 31, 2015 totaled approximately $3.1 million ($2.1 million after the associated tax benefit) consisting of charges in the first quarter of fiscal 2016 of $1.3 million in employee severance (reflected in selling, general, and administrative expenses), $1.2 million due to a retail store early lease termination agreement (reflected in selling, general, and administrative expenses), and $0.6 million related to an increase in income tax reserves for uncertain federal and state tax positions related to research and development tax credits (reflected in income tax expense).

1495320_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	How We Assess the Performance of Our Business In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of performance and financial measures.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Net Revenues Net revenues reflect revenues from the sale of our merchandise and from distribution and shipping and handling fees, less returns and discounts.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	Revenues for the Direct segment reflect sales through our full-line and factory outlet stores, verabradley.com, direct-to-consumer eBay sales, and our annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	Revenues for the Indirect segment reflect sales to specialty retail partners, department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, our wholesale business in Japan, and third party inventory liquidators.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	As of January 30, 2016 , our specialty retail locations have decreased to approximately 2,600 locations from their peak during fiscal 2013 of approximately 3,600 locations.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	We believe hyper-promotional activity, which we define as discounts of 60% or more, has been damaging to our brand.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Accordingly, we strategically reduced our use of this type of promotion both in our Direct stores and on verabradley.com during fiscal 2016.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Comparable Sales Comparable sales (including e-commerce) are calculated based upon our stores that have been open for at least 12 full fiscal months and net revenues from our e-commerce operations.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	Comparable store sales are calculated based solely upon our stores that have been open for at least 12 full fiscal months.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	Remodeled stores are included in comparable sales and comparable store sales unless the store was closed for a portion of the current or comparable prior period or the remodel resulted in a significant change in square footage.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	Some of our competitors and other retailers calculate comparable or same store sales differently than we do.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	As a result, data in this report regarding our comparable sales and comparable store sales may not be comparable to similar data made available by other companies.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Non-comparable sales include sales from stores not included in comparable sales or comparable store sales.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Measuring the change in year-over-year comparable sales allows us to evaluate how our store base and e-commerce operations are performing.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	Various factors affect our comparable sales, including:
1495320_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Timing and success of promotional and advertising efforts.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	In recent years, comparable store sales have declined.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	With that in mind, we are slowing our full-line store opening plan in fiscal 2017 to four new stores from an average of approximately 20 new stores in prior years.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S2	We will continue to evaluate our plans for store openings in future years in light of demand and store performance.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S3	Gross Profit Gross profit is equal to our net revenues less our cost of sales.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S4	Cost of sales includes the direct cost of purchased merchandise, distribution center costs, operations overhead, duty, and all inbound freight costs incurred.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P20_S5	The components of our reported cost of sales may not be comparable to those of other retail and wholesale companies.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	Gross profit can be impacted by changes in volume; fluctuations in sales price; operational efficiencies, such as leveraging of fixed costs; promotional activities, such as free shipping; commodity prices, such as cotton prices; and labor costs.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S1	A expenses include selling; advertising, marketing, and product development; and administrative.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S2	Selling expenses include Direct business expenses such as store expenses, employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs, as well as Indirect business expenses consisting primarily of employee compensation and other expenses associated with sales to Indirect retailers.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S3	Advertising, marketing, and product development expenses include employee compensation, media costs, creative production expenses, marketing agency fees, new product design costs, public relations expenses, and market research expenses.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S4	A portion of our advertising expenses may be reimbursed by Indirect retailers, and such amount is classified as other income.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S5	Administrative expenses include employee compensation for corporate functions, corporate headquarters occupancy costs, consulting and software expenses, and charitable donations.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S6	Other Income We support many of our Indirect retailers marketing efforts by distributing certain catalogs and promotional mailers to current and prospective customers.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S7	Our Indirect retailers reimburse us for a portion of the cost to produce these materials.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S8	Reimbursement received is recorded as other income.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S9	The related cost to design, produce, and distribute the catalogs and mailers is recorded as SG A expense.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P21_S10	Other income also includes proceeds from the sales of tickets to our annual outlet sale.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	Operating Income Operating income is equal to gross profit less SG A expenses plus other income.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	Operating income excludes interest income, interest expense, and income taxes.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P22_S2	Income from Continuing Operations Income from continuing operations is equal to operating income less net interest expense and income taxes.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P22_S3	Loss from Discontinued Operations, Net of Taxes Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes, is equal to the loss from the results of operations related to the direct Japan business, which was exited in the third quarter of fiscal 2015, adjusted for the associated tax benefit.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P22_S4	Net Income Net income is equal to the sum of income from continuing operations and loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes.

1495320_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	We believe that cash flows from operating activities and the availability of borrowings under our second amended and restated credit agreement will be sufficient to meet working capital requirements, anticipated capital expenditures, share repurchases, and debt payments for the foreseeable future.

1495320_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	The Credit Agreement provides for certain credit facilities to VBD in an aggregate principal amount not to initially exceed $125.0 million, the proceeds of which will be used for general corporate purposes of VBD and its subsidiaries, including but not limited to Vera Bradley International, LLC and Vera Bradley Sales, LLC (collectively, the Named Subsidiaries ).
1495320_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	Amounts outstanding under the Credit Agreement bear interest, at VBD's option, at a per annum rate equal to either (A) the Alternate Base Rate ( ABR ) plus the Applicable Margin, where the ABR is the highest of (i) the prime rate, (ii) the federal funds rate plus 0.5%, and (iii) Adjusted LIBOR for a one-month interest period plus 1%, and the Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 0.00% to 0.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio or (B) Adjusted LIBOR plus the Applicable Margin, where Adjusted LIBOR means LIBOR, as adjusted for statutory reserve requirements for eurocurrency liabilities, and Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 1.00% to 1.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	Any loans made, or letters of credit issued, pursuant to the Credit Agreement mature on July 15, 2020.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	As of January 30, 2016 , the Company had borrowing availability of $125.0 million under the agreement.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	VBD's obligations under the Credit Agreement are guaranteed by the Company and the Named Subsidiaries.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	The obligations of VBD under the Credit Agreement are secured by first priority security interests in all of the respective assets of VBD, the Company, and the Named Subsidiaries and a pledge of the equity interests of VBD and the Named Subsidiaries.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	The Credit Agreement contains various restrictive covenants, including restrictions on the Company's ability to dispose of assets, make acquisitions or investments, incur debt or liens, make distributions to stockholders or repurchase outstanding stock, enter into related party transactions and make capital expenditures, other than upon satisfaction of the conditions set forth in the Credit Agreement.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	The Company is also required to comply with certain financial and non-financial covenants, including maintaining a maximum leverage ratio, a minimum ratio of EBITDAR to the sum of interest expense plus rentals (as defined in the Credit Agreement), and a limit on capital expenditures.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	Upon an event of default, which includes certain customary events such as, among other things, a failure to make required payments when due, a failure to comply with covenants, certain bankruptcy and insolvency events, a material adverse change (as defined in the Credit Agreement), defaults under other material indebtedness, and a change in control, the lenders may accelerate amounts outstanding, terminate the agreement and foreclose on all collateral.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P44_S3	The Company was in compliance with these covenants as of January 30, 2016 .

1495320_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of our assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P49_S1	We evaluate our accounting policies, estimates, and judgments on an on-going basis.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	estimates and judgments on historical experience and various other factors that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P50_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions and conditions.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P50_S2	We evaluate the development and selection of our critical accounting policies and estimates and believe that the following policies and estimates involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity and are most significant to reporting our results of operations and financial position, and are therefore discussed as critical.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	The following critical accounting policies reflect the significant estimates and judgments used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	With respect to critical accounting policies, even a relatively minor variance between actual and expected experience can potentially have a materially favorable or unfavorable impact on subsequent results of operations.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P52_S1	Our historical results for the periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, however, have not been materially impacted by such variances.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P52_S2	More information on all of our significant accounting policies can be found in Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from the sale of our products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an estimate of shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	The adjustment of these shipments is based on actual delivery dates to the customer.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	Significant changes in shipping terms or delivery times could materially impact our revenues in a given period.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	We reserve for projected merchandise returns based on historical experience and other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P54_S1	In the Direct business returns are refunded by issuing the same payment tender of the original purchase and in the Indirect business the customer is issued a credit to its account to apply to outstanding invoices.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	Merchandise exchanges of the same product at the same price are not considered merchandise returns.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	Product returns are often resalable through our annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P55_S2	Additionally, we reserve for other potential product credits and for customer shipments not yet received.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P55_S3	The balance of the reserve for returns, customer shipments not yet received, and general credits was $3.3 million and $3.7 million as of January 30, 2016 , and January 31, 2015 , respectively.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	We sell gift cards with no expiration dates to customers and do not charge administrative fees on unused gift cards.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	Gift cards that we issue are recorded as a liability until they are redeemed, at which point revenue is recognized.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P56_S2	In addition, we recognize revenue on unredeemed gift cards when the likelihood of the gift card being redeemed is remote and there is no legal obligation to remit the value of unredeemed gift cards to the relevant jurisdictions.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	We determine the gift card breakage rate based on historical redemption patterns.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P58_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P58_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	We record valuation adjustments to our inventories, which are reflected in cost of sales, if the cost of specific inventory items on hand exceeds the amount we expect to realize from the ultimate sale or disposal of the inventory.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S1	This adjustment calculation requires us to make assumptions and estimates, which are based on factors such as merchandise seasonality, historical trends, and estimated sales and inventory levels, including sell-through of remaining units.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S2	In addition, as part of inventory adjustments, we provide for inventory shrinkage based on historical trends from our physical inventory counts.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S3	We perform physical inventory counts throughout the year and adjust the shrinkage provision accordingly.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S4	The balance of inventory adjustments was $5.5 million and $9.7 million for these matters as of the fiscal years ended January 30, 2016 , and January 31, 2015 , respectively.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S5	These adjustments related primarily to raw materials of retired patterns and styles and merchandise from the baby gift category, which was discontinued by the Company, and technology accessories.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S6	Fiscal 2015 included a raw materials reserve related to the closure of our domestic manufacturing facility.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P59_S7	We have the ability to move retired finished goods through a number of channels, including the annual outlet sale, our website and factory outlet stores, and through third-party liquidators as needed.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	Income Taxes Our effective tax rate is based on our pre-tax income, statutory tax rates, tax laws and regulations, and tax planning opportunities available in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P60_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our annual tax expense and in evaluating our tax positions.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P60_S2	We establish reserves to remove some or all of the tax benefit of any of our tax positions at the time we determine that the positions become uncertain based upon one of the following: (1) the tax position is not more likely than not to be sustained; (2) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but for a lesser amount; or (3) the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained, but not in the financial period in which the tax position was originally taken.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	Taxing authorities periodically audit our income tax returns.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P61_S1	We believe that our tax filing positions are reasonable and legally supportable.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P61_S2	Taxing authorities, however, may take a contrary position.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P61_S3	Our results of operations and effective tax rate in a given period could be impacted if, upon final resolution with taxing authorities, we prevail in positions for which we have established reserves, or are required to pay amounts in excess of established reserves.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	Valuation of Long-lived Assets Property, plant, and equipment assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	In evaluating an asset for recoverability, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset at the store level, the lowest identifiable level of cash flow, if applicable.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P63_S1	If the sum of the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the asset is less than the carrying value, we recognize a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, usually determined by an estimated discounted cash flow analysis of the asset.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Factors used in the valuation of long-lived assets include, but are not limited to, our plans for future operations, brand initiatives, recent operating results, and projected future cash flows.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	With respect to our stores, we analyze store economics, location within the shopping center, the size and shape of the space, and desirable co-tenancies in our selection process.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	Impairment charges are classified in SG A expenses and were $2.8 million and $0.4 million for the periods ended January 30, 2016 and January 31, 2015 , respectively.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	The discounted cash flow models used to estimate the applicable fair values involve numerous estimates and assumptions that are highly subjective.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	Changes to these estimates and assumptions could materially impact the fair value estimates.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S2	The estimates and assumptions critical to the overall fair value estimates include: (1) estimated future cash flow generated at the store level; and (2) discount rates used to derive the present value factors used in determining the fair values.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S3	These and other estimates and assumptions are impacted by economic conditions and our expectations and may change in the future based on period-specific facts and circumstances.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S4	If economic conditions were to deteriorate, future impairment charges may be required.
1495320_16_ITEM7_P67_S5	Transactions with Related Parties See Item 13, Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, and Director Independence, of this report for information regarding transactions with related parties.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are subject to interest rate risk in connection with borrowings under our second amended and restated credit agreement, which bear interest at variable rates.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The second amended and restated credit agreement allows for a revolving credit commitment of $125.0 million, bearing interest at a variable rate, based on (A) the ABR plus the Applicable Margin, where the ABR is the highest of (i) the prime rate, (ii) the federal funds rate plus 0.5%, and (iii) Adjusted LIBOR for a one-month interest period plus 1%, and the Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 0.00% to 0.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio or (B) Adjusted LIBOR plus the Applicable Margin, where Adjusted LIBOR means LIBOR, as adjusted for statutory reserve requirements for eurocurrency liabilities, and Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 1.00% to 1.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Assuming borrowings available under the second amended and restated credit agreement are fully extended, each quarter point increase or decrease in the interest rate would change our annual interest expense by approximately $0.3 million.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Impact of Inflation Our results of operations and financial condition are presented based on historical cost.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Although it is difficult to accurately measure the impact of inflation due to the imprecise nature of the estimates required, we believe the effects of inflation, if any, on our results of operations and financial condition have been immaterial.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Foreign Exchange Rate Risk We source a majority of our materials from various suppliers in China and South Korea.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Substantially all purchases and sales involving foreign persons are denominated in U.S. dollars, and therefore we do not hedge using any derivative instruments.
1495320_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Historically, we have not been impacted materially by changes in exchange rates.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P5_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P5_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P5_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P5_S4	In our opinion, Vera Bradley, Inc. and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 30, 2016, based on the COSO criteria.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	Description of the Company Vera Bradley is a leading designer of women s handbags and accessories, luggage and travel items, eyewear, and stationery and gifts.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S1	Founded in 1982 by friends Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia R. Miller, the brand s innovative designs, iconic patterns, and versatile styles offer women of all ages a colorful way to accessorize every look.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S2	Vera Bradley offers a unique, multi-channel sales model, as well as a focus on service and a high level of customer engagement.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S3	The Company sells its products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S4	The Direct business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products through the Company s full-line and factory outlet stores in the United States, verabradley.com, direct-to-consumer eBay sales, and the Company's annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P11_S5	As of January 30, 2016 , the Company operated 110 full-line stores and 40 factory outlet stores.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	The Indirect business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 2,600 specialty retail locations, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, the Company's wholesale business in Japan, and third party inventory liquidators.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P13_S1	The Company has eliminated intercompany balances and transactions in consolidation.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P13_S2	The Company utilizes a 52 - 53 week fiscal year ending on the Saturday closest to January 31.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P13_S3	As such, fiscal year 2016 , 2015 and 2014 ending on January 30, 2016 , January 31, 2015 and February 1, 2014 , respectively, each reflected a 52 -week period.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of the Company s assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses, as well as the disclosures relating to contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P14_S1	Significant areas requiring the use of management estimates include the valuation of inventories, accounts receivable valuation allowances, sales return allowances, and the useful lives of assets for depreciation or amortization.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P14_S2	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P14_S3	The Company revises its estimates and assumptions as new information becomes available.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P14_S4	Certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents represent cash on hand, deposits with financial institutions, and investments with an original maturity of three months or less.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	Concentration of Credit Risk The Company maintains nearly all of its cash and cash equivalents with one financial institution.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	The Company monitors the credit standing of this financial institution on a regular basis.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	Inventories Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P16_S1	Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) method.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P16_S2	Market is determined based on net realizable value, which includes costs to dispose.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P16_S3	Appropriate consideration is given to obsolescence, excess quantities, and other factors, including the popularity of a pattern or product, in evaluating net realizable value.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	Property, Plant, and Equipment Property, plant, and equipment are carried at cost and depreciated or amortized over the following estimated useful lives using the straight-line method:
1495320_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the life of the asset or the lease term.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	Lease terms typically range from five to ten years.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	When a decision is made to abandon property, plant, and equipment prior to the end of the previously estimated useful life, depreciation or amortization estimates are revised to reflect the use of the asset over the shortened estimated useful life.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	At the time of disposal, the cost of assets sold or retired and the related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts and any resulting loss is included in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	Property, plant, and equipment are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be recoverable.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	The reviews are conducted at the lowest identifiable level of cash flows.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	If the estimated undiscounted future cash flows related to the property, plant, and equipment are less than the carrying value, the Company recognizes a loss equal to the difference between the carrying value and the fair value, as further defined below in Fair Value of Financial Instruments.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	Routine maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs incurred in connection with acquiring, modifying, and installing internal-use software.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P23_S1	Capitalized costs are included in property, plant, and equipment and are amortized over three to five years .
1495320_16_ITEM8_P23_S2	Software costs that do not meet capitalization criteria are expensed as incurred.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	Revenue Recognition and Accounts Receivable Revenue from the sale of the Company s products is recognized upon customer receipt of the product when collection of the associated receivables is reasonably assured, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed and determinable, and ownership and risk of loss have been transferred to the customer, which, for e-commerce and most Indirect sales, reflects an adjustment for shipments that customers have not yet received.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	The adjustment of these shipments is based on actual delivery dates to the customer.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	Included in net revenues are product sales to Direct and Indirect customers, including amounts billed to customers for shipping fees.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	Costs related to shipping of product are classified in cost of sales in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P25_S2	Net revenues exclude sales taxes collected from customers and remitted to governmental authorities.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	Historical experience provides the Company the ability to reasonably estimate the amount of product sales that customers will return.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P26_S1	Product returns are often resalable through the Company s annual outlet sale or other channels.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P26_S2	Additionally, the Company reserves for other potential product credits granted to Indirect retailers.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P28_S2	In addition, the Company recognizes revenue on unredeemed gift cards when the likelihood of the gift card being redeemed is remote and there is no legal obligation to remit the value of unredeemed gift cards to the relevant jurisdictions.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	Costs and related expenses to purchase and distribute the products are recorded as cost of sales when the related revenues are recognized.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	The Company has leases that contain rent holidays and predetermined, fixed escalations of minimum rentals.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	For each of these leases, the Company recognizes the related rent expense on a straight-line basis commencing on the date of initial possession of the leased property.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P32_S2	The Company records the difference between the recognized rent expense and the amount payable under the lease as a deferred rent liability.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P32_S3	As of January 30, 2016 and January 31, 2015 , deferred rent liability was $11.5 million and $8.9 million , respectively, and is included within other long-term liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	These allowances generally are in the form of cash received by the Company from its landlords as part of the negotiated lease terms.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P33_S2	The Company records each tenant-improvement allowance as a deferred credit and amortizes the allowance on a straight-line basis as a reduction to rent expense over the term of the lease, commencing on the possession date.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P33_S3	As of January 30, 2016 and January 31, 2015 , the deferred lease credit liability was $16.2 million and $13.8 million , respectively.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P33_S4	Of this, $2.3 million and $1.8 million is included within other accrued liabilities and $13.9 million and $12.0 million is included within other long-term liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as of January 30, 2016 and January 31, 2015 , respectively.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	The Company charges costs associated with the opening of new stores to selling, general, and administrative expenses as incurred.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P34_S1	Selling, general, and administrative expenses also include store operating costs, store employee compensation, and store occupancy and supply costs.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P35_S1	Under these provisions, for its awards of restricted stock and restricted-stock units, the Company recognizes stock-based compensation expense in an amount equal to the fair market value of the underlying stock on the grant date of the respective award.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P39_S1	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value are classified using the following hierarchy, which is based upon the transparency of inputs to the valuation as of the measurement date:
1495320_16_ITEM8_P39_S2	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities; Level 2 Inputs, other than the quoted prices in active markets, that are observable either directly or indirectly; Level 3 Unobservable inputs based on the Company s own assumptions.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	The classification of fair value measurements within the hierarchy is based upon the lowest level of input that is significant to the measurement.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	The carrying amounts reflected on the Consolidated Balance Sheets for cash and cash equivalents, receivables, other current assets, and payables as of January 30, 2016 , and January 31, 2015 , approximated their fair values.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	The carrying amount for the credit agreement approximates fair value at January 30, 2016 , and January 31, 2015 , as the interest rates of these borrowings fluctuate with the market.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	The credit agreement falls within Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company has certain assets that are measured on a non-recurring basis under circumstances and events described in Note 4.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P43_S1	The categorization of the framework to price these assets are level 3 due to subjective nature of unobservable inputs.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	Income Taxes The Company accrues income taxes payable or refundable and recognizes deferred tax assets and liabilities based on differences between the book and tax bases of assets and liabilities.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	The Company measures deferred tax assets and liabilities using enacted rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse, and recognizes the effect of a change in enacted rates in the period of enactment.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P44_S2	The Company establishes liabilities for uncertain positions taken or expected to be taken in income tax returns, using a more-likely-than-not recognition threshold.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P44_S3	The Company includes in income tax expense any interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers .
1495320_16_ITEM8_P45_S1	This guidance requires companies to recognize revenue in a manner that depicts the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in amounts that reflect the consideration to which a company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P45_S2	The new standard also will result in enhanced disclosures about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P45_S3	The standard allows for either a full retrospective or a modified retrospective transition method.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-14 to defer the effective date of ASU 2014-09 for all entities by one year to annual periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period, which for the Company is fiscal 2019.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P46_S1	Earlier application is permitted as of the original effective date, annual reporting periods beginning after December 2016, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P46_S2	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard, including the transition method, on its consolidated results of operations, financial position and cash flows.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	The guidance is effective for annual or interim reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2016.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P47_S2	Early adoption is permitted for financial statements that have not been previously issued.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P47_S3	The standard allows for either a full retrospective or modified retrospective transition method.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	Under this new guidance, the Company will be required to present these costs in its condensed consolidated balance sheets as a direct deduction from the related debt liability.

1495320_16_ITEM8_P58_S0	National Association, as administrative agent, Wells Fargo Bank, National Association, as syndication agent, and KeyBank National Association, as documentation agent (the Credit Agreement ), which amended and restated the Company's prior credit agreement.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P58_S1	The Credit Agreement provides for certain credit facilities to VBD in an aggregate principal amount not to initially exceed $125.0 million , the proceeds of which will be used for general corporate purposes of VBD and its subsidiaries, including but not limited to Vera Bradley International, LLC and Vera Bradley Sales, LLC (collectively, the Named Subsidiaries ).
1495320_16_ITEM8_P58_S2	Amounts outstanding under the Credit Agreement bear interest, at VBD's option, at a per annum rate equal to either (A) the Alternate Base Rate ( ABR ) plus the Applicable Margin, where the ABR is the highest of (i) the prime rate, (ii) the federal funds rate plus 0.5% , and (iii) Adjusted LIBOR for a one-month interest period plus 1% , and the Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 0.00% to 0.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio or (B) Adjusted LIBOR plus the Applicable Margin, where Adjusted LIBOR means LIBOR, as adjusted for statutory reserve requirements for eurocurrency liabilities, and Applicable Margin is a percentage ranging from 1.00% to 1.70% depending upon the Company's leverage ratio.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	Any loans made, or letters of credit issued, pursuant to the Credit Agreement mature on July 15, 2020 .

1495320_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	The obligations of VBD under the Credit Agreement are secured by first priority security interests in all of the respective assets of VBD, the Company, and the Named Subsidiaries and a pledge of the equity interests of VBD and the Named Subsidiaries.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Credit Agreement contains various restrictive covenants, including restrictions on the Company's ability to dispose of assets, make acquisitions or investments, incur debt or liens, make distributions to stockholders or repurchase outstanding stock, enter into related party transactions and make capital expenditures, other than upon satisfaction of the conditions set forth in the Credit Agreement.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P61_S1	The Company is also required to comply with certain financial and non-financial covenants, including maintaining a maximum leverage ratio, a minimum ratio of EBITDAR to the sum of interest expense plus rentals (as defined in the Credit Agreement), and a limit on capital expenditures.
1495320_16_ITEM8_P61_S2	Upon an event of default, which includes certain customary events such as, among other things, a failure to make required payments when due, a failure to comply with covenants, certain bankruptcy and insolvency events, a material adverse change (as defined in the Credit Agreement), defaults under other material indebtedness, and a change in control, the lenders may accelerate amounts outstanding, terminate the agreement and foreclose on all collateral.

1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vera Bradley is a leading designer of women s handbags, luggage and travel items, fashion and home accessories, and unique gifts.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	Founded in 1982 by friends Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia R. Miller, the brand s innovative designs, iconic patterns, and brilliant colors continue to inspire and connect women.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	Vera Bradley offers a unique, multi-channel sales model, as well as a focus on service and a high level of customer engagement.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S3	The Company sells its products through two reportable segments: Direct and Indirect.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S4	The Direct business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products through the Company s full-line and factory outlet stores in the United States, verabradley.com, direct-to-consumer eBay sales, and the Company s annual outlet sale in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P0_S5	As of January 28, 2017 , the Company operated 113 full-line stores and 46 factory outlet stores.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Indirect business consists of sales of Vera Bradley products to approximately 2,600 specialty retail locations, substantially all of which are located in the United States, as well as department stores, national accounts, third party e-commerce sites, the Company's wholesale customer in Japan, and third-party inventory liquidators.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	For financial information about our reportable segments, refer to Note 16 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Part II, Item 8.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this report.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our History Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller founded the Company in 1982 in Fort Wayne, Indiana, after recognizing a lack of stylish travel accessories in the market.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	Within weeks, the friends created Vera Bradley, named after Ms. Bradley Baekgaard s mother, and began manufacturing and marketing their distinctive products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P2_S2	The founders, together with past and present members of the executive management team, have been instrumental in our growth and success.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P2_S3	The following timeline sets forth a summary of significant milestones in Vera Bradley s history by calendar year:
1495320_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	Barbara Bradley Baekgaard and Patricia Miller launched Vera Bradley by introducing three products: the handbag, the sports bag, and the duffel bag.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	Ernst Young honored our Co-Founders with an Entrepreneur of the Year award.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	To accommodate the increasing number of attendees, we relocated our annual outlet sale from a tent in our parking lot to its present location at the Allen County War Memorial Coliseum Exposition Center in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	We founded our primary philanthropy, the Vera Bradley Foundation for Breast Cancer.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	Our products were sold in all 50 states through Indirect retailers.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	We launched the Vera Bradley Visual Merchandising Program, providing our retail partners a framework for presenting the brand and merchandising our products in a consistent manner.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	We launched our e-commerce business through our website, verabradley.com.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	We opened a state-of-the-art distribution facility in Roanoke, Indiana and also opened our first full-line store at the Natick Collection, in greater Boston.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	We opened our first outlet store at Chicago Premium Outlets in Aurora, Illinois.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	We completed our initial public offering.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	We opened the Vera Bradley Design Center in Roanoke, Indiana, and launched our products in Dillard's department stores.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	We completed a 200,000 square-foot expansion of our distribution facility in Roanoke, Indiana; increased our presence to all Dillard s locations; and launched a relationship with Von Maur department stores.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	We migrated verabradley.com to a more responsive design, providing an enhanced shopping experience and improved product viewing regardless of the device being used to shop.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	We introduced laser-cut, leather, faux leather, and full coordinating collections; began our relationship with Macy's; and launched our first national ad campaign.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	We launched several new collections including Streeterville, Preppy Poly, and Collegiate; introduced line extensions such as our fragrance collection and the expansion of our jewelry collection; launched our I AM national ad campaign; increased our presence in Macy's; introduced our products in Belk and Bon-Ton department stores; and made further improvements to verabradley.com, including enhanced search.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	It's Good to Be a Girl national marketing campaign; and expanded our collegiate collection to over 70 schools.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	The passion for design and customer service established by our founders has driven our Company for over 30 years and remains the cornerstone of Vera Bradley today.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S1	Chief Creative Officer, Ms. Baekgaard, continues to provide guidance on our creative efforts, including product development and store design.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S2	Ms. Miller retired in October 2012 as our National Spokesperson, but continues to serve on the Board of Directors along with Ms. Baekgaard.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S3	Our long-term vision is to build on the Company's rich heritage and establish Vera Bradley as a premium global lifestyle brand, expand our customer reach and grow our customer connections.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S4	Our long-term strategic plan is centered upon the three planks of product, distribution, and marketing.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S5	We call our target aspirational customer the Day Maker.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S6	She is organized, thoughtful and, most of all, appreciates femininity and beauty - in color, print and thoughtful details.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S7	We are focused on creating beautiful solutions for the Day Maker and believe we have a great opportunity to attract more Day Makers to our brand through our product offerings, our distribution channels, and our marketing efforts.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S8	We have identified five key businesses where we can offer the Day Maker beautiful solutions that we believe will propel our future growth.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S9	We are optimizing our existing core product portfolio and expanding into relevant new categories.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P19_S10	We will continue to use licenses and strategic partnerships as appropriate to expand our product categories.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our Fashion Bag and Accessories business continues to be our largest opportunity and allows us to showcase our innovation, function, and fashion.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	Travel remains a core differentiator for Vera Bradley and allows us to both embrace our heritage and to showcase newness and functionality with products like Lighten Up and our unique collapsible luggage.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our Campus business has been successful, and we believe further expansion of our Collegiate Collection will help continue to propel our Campus authority forward.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	Wellness and Beauty is a growing category as our Day Maker is looking for experiential events and wants to find wellness and beauty products that enhance her holistically.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P23_S1	Our home and body fragrance collection and our current line of multi-purpose sport bags play into this theme.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	We believe Home can continue to be a significant growth opportunity for Vera Bradley, with market attractiveness and a great brand fit.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	The Day Maker s fashion statement is often her home.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	Licensing will play a key role in the home area.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	In each of these areas, fabric, pattern innovation, and newness remain critical in order to stay relevant.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	Vera Bradley products are available wherever our consumer chooses to shop including full-line and factory outlet stores, online, and department and specialty retail stores.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S1	We continue to focus on tightly integrating our multi-channel business by strengthening our Direct distribution channel (including full-line stores, factory outlet stores, and e-commerce), further developing our department store and other Indirect channel relationships and right-sizing and working to strengthen the performance in our specialty retail channel.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S2	In 2007 and 2009, we opened our first full-line and factory outlet stores, respectively.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S3	We believe there continue to be long-term opportunities for new stores throughout the United States.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S4	We opened four new full-line and six new factory outlet stores in fiscal 2017; however, we are continuing to slow our short-term plans for new store openings until we begin to produce comparable store sales growth.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S5	We do not currently plan to open any new full-line stores in fiscal 2018.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S6	In fact, we expect to relocate or close up to 15 underperforming full-line stores over the next two years.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S7	In our full-line stores, we are continuing to work to drive traffic and sales through building a service and selling culture, nurturing more community outreach, and building more localized assortments.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S8	During fiscal 2017, we refreshed 14 full-line stores to reflect our new branding including updates to the storefront facade, logo, and interior.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S9	We also completed facade updates at 15 of our newest full-line stores to reflect our new logo.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S10	We are continuing our refresh program and expect that about half of our full-line stores will be updated by the end of fiscal 2018.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S11	We plan to add six new factory outlet stores in fiscal 2018.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P27_S12	At January 28, 2017, approximately 70% of the product in the outlet channel was made specifically for our factory outlet stores.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	In 2006, we began selling directly to consumers through verabradley.com.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S1	In fiscal 2017, we had approximately 53 million visits to our website.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S2	Building our digital flagship remains a key part of our distribution strategy.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S3	The redesign and conversion of our website to a new platform was completed in February 2017.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S4	This new platform offers enhanced ease of shopping and incremental functionality including an upgraded mobile experience; additional navigation and search enhancements; improved product pages with enhanced imagery, product videos, and user-generated content; and new capabilities like eGift cards and order on line, pick up in store.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S5	The new platform also gives us capabilities to create deeper customer relationships and create value through more personalization and strategic customization.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S6	Our department store relationships allow us to expose our brand to new customers and showcase our new product assortments.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S7	We are currently in over 730 department store locations, including Macy's, Dillard's, Belk, Bon-Ton, and Von Maur.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S8	In the department stores, we are continuing to work on enhancing our brand presentation and to expand our lifestyle brand offerings.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S9	The specialty retail channel is the heritage of our business and remains very important to us.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S10	We continue to add select accounts while discontinuing unproductive accounts.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S11	While the specialty retail business is becoming a smaller percentage of our total revenue base, it is still an important piece of our business, and we are working to stabilize it by segmenting specific products to this channel and assisting retailers with assortment planning.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S12	We have a small wholesale presence in Japan.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P28_S13	We are exploring the possibility of expanding into other countries in the long-term but do not foresee any additional international country expansion in fiscal 2018.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	Marketing and brand positioning are both critical elements as we continue to engage new consumers and strengthen our bond with our existing customers.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S1	During fiscal 2017, our focus was to increase brand relevancy, desire for the brand, and purchase intent.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S2	We activated our new branding and brand positioning in fiscal 2017, which included updating elements of our visual identity such as our logo and further evolving our marketing to speak more directly to the Day Maker.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S3	We believe that highlighting our new product and enhancing our brand creative to assure our customer that we understand her will give the Day Maker a new reason to look at Vera Bradley.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S4	Well-timed and well-executed brand activation is critical to increasing our brand relevancy and increasing purchase intent.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S5	Through comprehensive consumer research, we have designed a media plan that we believe effectively targets our Day Maker customers and attracts both lapsed and new Day Maker consumers to our brand, reaching them where they already are looking and giving them content that showcases our beautiful solutions.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S6	Our media efforts include a fully-integrated mix of digital, social, experiential, and print, with our goal being to surround the Day Maker with our brand.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P29_S7	We believe the following competitive strengths differentiate us within the marketplace:

1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S0	Manufacturing and Supply Chain Model Our multi-country manufacturing and supply chain model is designed to achieve efficient, timely, and accurate order fulfillment while maintaining appropriate levels of inventory.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S1	Our manufacturing and sourcing strategy is part of the larger cross-functional product development process.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S2	The overall objective for our sourcing team is to build and sustain collaborative partnerships throughout our supply chain, with a focus on identifying appropriate countries and partners to manufacture our products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S3	The sourcing team leverages its expertise in negotiation, relationship management, and change management to maintain a strong global supply chain.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S4	We strive to maintain the appropriate balance of inventory to enable us to provide a high level of service to our customers, including prompt and accurate delivery of our products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S5	We have an active and nimble sales and operations planning process that helps us balance the supply and demand issues that we encounter in our business, optimize our inventory levels, and anticipate inventory needs.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P54_S6	We have also integrated our planning, forecasting, and segmentation processes under one function called Merchandise Planning and Allocation.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S0	Approximately half of our products are cotton-based.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S1	Our other fabrics include nylon, polyester, microfiber, leather, and faux leather.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S2	We source our materials from various suppliers in Asia, with the majority coming from China and South Korea.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S3	Our global sourcing team works with select suppliers enabling us to optimize the mix of cost, lead time, quality, and reliability within our global supply network.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S4	All of our suppliers must comply with our quality standards, and we use only a limited number of pre-approved suppliers who have demonstrated a commitment to delivering the highest quality products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P55_S5	In April 2016, we opened an office in Hong Kong to lead the global supply chain in Asia, including the oversight of sourcing and procurement.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P56_S0	The majority of our finished goods, not sourced through licenses or strategic partners, are manufactured by a variety of global manufacturers located primarily in China, Vietnam and Cambodia.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P56_S1	We are not dependent upon any single manufacturer for our products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P56_S2	When determining the size of orders placed with our manufacturers, we take into account forward-looking demand, lead times for specific products, current inventory levels, and minimum order quantity requirements.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P57_S0	Overseas production has resulted in substantial cost savings and a reduction of capital investment.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P57_S1	With the oversight of our office in Hong Kong and our independent contractors, we believe these financial benefits have been realized without sacrificing the level of quality inherent in our products or service to our customers.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S0	In 2007, we consolidated our warehousing and shipping functions into one distribution center, located in Roanoke, Indiana.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S1	In fiscal 2013 and fiscal 2015, we expanded the facility by 200,000 and 10,000 square-feet, respectively, which resulted in a total distribution center space of 428,500 square-feet.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S2	This automated, computerized facility allows Vera Bradley employees to receive information directly from the order-collection center and quickly identify the products and quantities necessary for a particular order.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S3	The expansion resulted in capacity gains in the areas of inbound receiving, inventory storage, order fulfillment, value-add processing, and shipping.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S4	The facility s technology enables us to more accurately process and pack orders, as well as track shipments and inventory.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S5	We believe that our systems for the processing and shipment of orders from our distribution center have enabled us to improve our overall customer service through enhanced order accuracy and reduced turnaround time.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S6	Our products are shipped primarily via third-party common carriers to our stores, our Indirect retailers, and department stores, and directly to our customers who purchase through our website.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S7	We believe we are positioned well to support the order fulfillment requirements of our business, including business generated through our website.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S8	We believe that high levels of automation and technology are essential to maintain our competitive position.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S9	We maintain computer hardware, systems applications, and networks to enhance and accelerate the design process, to support the sale and distribution of our products to our customers, and to improve the integration and efficiency of our operations.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S10	Our management information systems are designed to provide, among other things, comprehensive order processing, production, accounting, and management information for the product development, retail, sales, marketing, distribution, finance, and human resources functions of our business.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P58_S11	We use several systems, including MICROS-Retail, SAP, JDA, and SCALE for our information technology requirements.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S0	Competition We face strong competition in each of the product lines and markets in which we compete.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S1	We believe that all of our products are in similar competitive positions with respect to the number of competitors they face and the level of competition within each product line.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S2	Due to the number of different products we offer, it is not practicable for us to quantify the number of competitors we face.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S3	Our products compete with other branded products within their product categories and with private label products sold by retailers.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S4	In our Indirect business, we compete with numerous manufacturers, importers, and distributors of handbags, accessories, and other products for the limited space available for the display of such products to the consumer.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P59_S5	Moreover, the general availability of contract manufacturing allows new entrants access to the markets in which we compete, which may increase the number of competitors and adversely affect our competitive position and our business.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S0	In our Direct business, we compete against other independent retailers, department stores, catalog retailers, gift retailers, and Internet businesses that engage in the retail sale of similar products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S1	The market for handbags, in particular, is highly competitive.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S2	Our competitors include not only established companies that are expanding their production and marketing of handbags, but also frequent new entrants to the market.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S3	We directly compete with wholesalers and direct sellers of branded handbags and accessories, such as Coach, Michael Kors, Nine West, Dooney Bourke, Kate Spade, Fossil, Brahmin, and Tory Burch.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S4	In varying degrees, depending on the product category involved, we compete on the basis of design (aesthetic appeal), quality (construction), function, price point, distribution, and brand positioning.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S5	We believe that our primary competitive advantages are consumer recognition of our brand, customer loyalty, product development expertise, and our widespread presence through our multi-channel distribution model.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S6	Some of our competitors have achieved significant recognition for their brand names or have substantially greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other resources than we do.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P60_S7	Further, we may face new competitors and increased competition from existing competitors as we expand into new markets and increase our presence in existing markets.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S0	Copyrights and Trademarks The development of new patterns includes the design of primary and secondary prints.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S1	Once developed, we generally copyright our patterns as appropriate.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S2	We currently have approximately 820 copyrights.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S3	We also own all of the material trademark rights used in connection with the production, marketing, and distribution of all of our products, both in the United States and in the other countries in which our products are principally sold.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S4	We aggressively police our trademarks and copyrights and pursue infringers and counterfeiters both domestically and internationally.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P61_S5	Our trademarks will remain in existence for as long as we continue to use and renew them in advance of their expiration dates.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S0	Employees As of January 28, 2017 , we had approximately 3,100 employees.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S1	Of the total, approximately 2,450 were engaged in retail selling positions, approximately 315 were engaged in distribution, sourcing and quality functions, approximately 35 were engaged in product design, and approximately 300 were engaged in corporate support and administrative functions.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S2	None of our employees are represented by a union.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S3	We believe that our relations with our employees are good, and we have never encountered a significant work stoppage.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S4	Many of our imported products are subject to existing or potential duties, tariffs, or quotas that may limit the quantity of products that we may import into the United States and other countries or impact the cost of such products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S5	To date, we have not been restricted by quotas in the operation of our business, and customs duties have not comprised a material portion of the total cost of a majority of our products.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S6	In addition, we are subject to foreign governmental regulation and trade restrictions, including U.S. retaliation against prohibited foreign practices, with respect to our product sourcing and international sales operations.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S7	We are subject to federal, state, local, and foreign laws and regulations governing environmental matters, including the handling, transportation, and disposal of our products and our non-hazardous and hazardous substances and wastes, as well as emissions and discharges into the environment, including discharges to air, surface water, and groundwater.
1495320_17_ITEM1_P62_S8	Failure to comply with such laws and regulations could result in costs for corrective action, penalties, or the imposition of other liabilities.

1495320_17_ITEM1_P63_S1	If we violate any laws or regulations, however, it could have a material adverse effect on our business or financial performance.
